<!-- Image with unknown copyright status removed: [[Image:Mokrecov.jpg|frame|Wikipedia Encyclopedia]] --> '''Mikhail Pavlovich Mokretsov''' ({{lang-ru|Михаил Павлович Мокрецов}}) (born February 9, 1961, [[Udmurt ASSR]]) is a [[Russia]]n businessman and state official. He has been the Chief of the Federal Tax Service since February 21, 2007.
Mikhail Mokretsov graduated the Leningrad Institute of Finance & Economics (currently [[Saint Petersburg State University of Economics and Finance]]) in 1984 with a degree in economics.
After graduating he served for two years as an officer in the [[Soviet Army]].
In the years 1986 - 1988 he worked as a Deputy Accountant General at the "Bolshevik" plant in [[Leningrad]]. The plant was producing high-tech equipment for the [[Soviet Army]].
In 1989 - 1992 was an Accountant General at "DAP International", a company operating in the sphere of international trade.
Later, in 1992 - 1996 worked as a Financial Director in the agricultural company "Rosagrico".
From 1996 to year 2000 was a Director General of the consulting company "A&P Audit", which he also co-owned.
Since year 2000 has been a state official. First, Mr. Mokretsov worked as a Chief of the Control & Inspection Department of the [[Saint Petersburg]] Directorate of the Tax Ministry of Russia. Later he was promoted to the position of Deputy Chief of the [[Saint Petersburg]] Directorate of the Tax Ministry of Russia.
In 2004 he moved to [[Moscow]] and became the Chief of the [[Moscow]] Directorate of the Tax Ministry of Russia. The same year he was later appointed a Chief of the International Cooperation Department of the Tax Ministry of Russia.
On November 19, 2004 Mokretsov became the Deputy Chief of the Federal Tax Service, which Tax Ministry of Russia was reorganized into.
On February 21, 2007 he was appointed as the Chief of the Federal Tax Service.
Mikhail Mokretsov is famous for his strict policy against tax legislation offenders & is considered to be one of the closest allies of the Defence Minister of the Russian Federation [[Anatoliy Serdyukov]] and [[Prime Minister of Russia]] [[Viktor Zubkov]].
Mikhail Mokretsov is married & has a son named Alexander (born 1984).
In 2006 Mikhail Mokretsov was given the title of Honoured Economist of the Russian Federation.
On April 7, 2010 Mikhail Mokretsov was appointed Chief of Staff of [[Ministry of Defence of the Russian Federation]].
==External links== * http://lenta.ru/lib/14177348/ * https://web.archive.org/web/20071102040948/http://www.nalog.ru/index.php?topic=leader * https://web.archive.org/web/20071022122610/http://www.government.ru/government/executivepowerservices/ministries/minfin/podved/nalog/rukovodstvo/5736811.htm * https://archive.is/20070206035930/http://www.mil.ru/847/852/1160/index.shtml
{{DEFAULTSORT:Mokretsov, Mikhail}} [[Category:Russian economists]] [[Category:Russian politicians]] [[Category:Russian businesspeople]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:1961 births]]

{{Infobox officeholder | honorific-prefix = [[Sardar (IRGC)|Sardar]] | name = Mohsen Rafighdoost | image = Mohsan Rafighdoost 1394.jpg | caption = Mohsen Rafighdoost in 2015 | birth_date = {{birth year and age|1940}} | birth_place = [[Tehran]], [[Iran]] | office1 = [[Mostazafan Foundation|Head of Mostazafan Foundation]] | appointer1 = [[Ali Khamenei]] | term_start1 = 6 September 1989 | term_end1 = 22 July 1999 | predecessor1 = [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]] | successor1 = [[Mohammad Forouzandeh]] | order2 = [[Ministry of Revolutionary Guards|Minister of Revolutionary Guards]] | term_start2 = November 1982 | term_end2 = 20 September 1988 | president2 = [[Ali Khamenei]] | primeminister2 = [[Mir-Hossein Mousavi]] | predecessor2 = ''Ministry founded'' | successor2 = [[Ali Shamkhani]] | party = [[Islamic Coalition Party]] | allegiance = [[Iran]] | branch = [[Revolutionary Guards]] | serviceyears = 1979–present | rank = [[Brigadier general]] | battles = [[Iran–Iraq War]] | mawards = [[File:Order of Nasr Ribbon.svg|50px]] [[Nasr Medal of Honor]] }} '''Mohsen Rafighdoost''' (also '''Rafiqdoost''', {{lang-fa|محسن رفیقدوست}}) is an Iranian [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps|Revolutionary Guards]] military officer and politician. He is a member of the [[Islamic Coalition Party]].<ref>{{cite encyclopedia|title =JAMʿIYAT-E MOʾTALEFA-YE ESLĀMI i. Hayʾathā-ye Moʾtalefa-ye Eslāmi 1963-79|encyclopedia=[[Encyclopædia Iranica]]|date=February 20, 2013|orig-year=December 15, 2008|publisher=Bibliotheca Persica Press|location=New York City|url =http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/jamiyat-e-motalefa-i|volume= XIV|last1= Rahnema|first1=Ali|access-date=March 15, 2016|series=Fasc. 5|pages=483–500|chapter-url=http://www.iranicaonline.org/articles/jamiyat-e-motalefa-ii|chapter=ii. Jamʿiyat-e Moʾtalefa and the Islamic Revolution}}</ref>
==Background== Rafighdoost's background is that of a ''[[bazaari]]'', the traditional class of people who work in the [[bazaar]].<ref name="Kaplan, 1996 p.201">Kaplan, ''The Ends of the Earth, (1996), p.201</ref> His father was a vegetable and fruit merchant at the Tehran bazaar.<ref name="Klebnikov">[https://www.forbes.com/forbes/2003/0721/056_3.html Millionaire mullahs] by Paul Klebnikov. ''Forbes'', July 7, 2003, accessed 15-May-2009</ref>
==Military career== Mohsen Rafighdoost was the chief of [[Ruhollah Khomeini]]'s security detail in 1979 during the [[Iranian Revolution]], and helped found the [[Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps|Revolutionary Guards]] who helped [[Consolidation of the Iranian Revolution#Suppression of opposition|eliminate opposition]] to theocratic rule in the [[Islamic Republic]].
He is noted for having driven Ayatollah [[Ruhollah Khomeini]], the leader of the Revolution, from the [[Tehran]] international airport into Tehran, during Khomeini's triumphant return to Iran from exile, while millions of Iranians crowded the road to welcome Khomeini back. He has told journalists this was the most important day of his life and "crowds were all over the car, touching and hanging on to it."<ref>Kaplan, ''The Ends of the Earth'', (1996), p.200</ref>
He served from 1982 to 1989 as Minister of the Revolutionary Guards<ref>[http://www.iricrimes.org/wanted.asp Islamic Republic of Iran Crimes] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061026212758/http://www.iricrimes.org/wanted.asp |date=2006-10-26 }}</ref> where he quashed internal dissent and obtained weapons from abroad for the [[Iran–Iraq War]].
Rafighdoost said in a 2014 interview that he twice suggested to Khomeini that Iran develop [[weapons of mass destruction]] to counter their [[Iraqi chemical weapons program#Use in the Iran–Iraq War, 1983–1988|use by Saddam Hussein]]. Rafighdoost claimed that both times Khomeini rejected the idea, reasoning that it would be against Islam.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Porter|first1=Gareth|title=When the Ayatollah Said No to Nukes|url=https://foreignpolicy.com/articles/2014/10/16/when_the_ayatollah_said_no_to_nukes_iran_khomeini|work=Foreign Policy|date=17 October 2014}}</ref>
==Business career== With the election of [[Ali Akbar Hashemi Rafsanjani]] he was appointed head of the Mostazafan Foundation or ''[[Bonyad-e Mostazafen va Janbazan]]'' (Foundation of the Oppressed), "the second-largest commercial enterprise" in Iran behind the state-owned [[National Iranian Oil Company]]<ref name="Klebnikov"/> where he remained until 1999.
Since 1999, Mohsen Rafighdoost has been the Director of the Noor Foundation. The Foundation reportedly owns apartment blocks and "makes an estimated $200 million importing pharmaceuticals, sugar and construction materials."<ref>http://rand.org/pubs/monographs/2008/RAND_MG821.pdf</ref>
==Controversy== In 1995, Mohsen Rafighdoost's brother, Morteza Rafighdoost, was sentenced to ten years imprisonment for a bank fraud.<ref>[http://www.iran-press-service.com/articles/bonyad_2379923.html THE CHANGE AT THE DEPRIVED FOUNDATION A CONCESSION TO KHATAMI?]</ref> After this, Supreme Leader [[Ali Khamenei]] appointed a board of trustees and made the Bonyad-e Mostazafen va Janbazan subject to [[Majlis|parliamentary]] scrutiny.<ref>[http://iranpoliticsclub.net/library/english-library/lori%27s-song1/index.htm#On%20Mohammad%20Forouzandeh On Mohammad Forouzandeh]</ref>
Rafighdoost's personal fortune is said to be worth the equivalent of many millions of dollars.<ref name="Kaplan, 1996 p.201" /> When asked about his personal wealth, Rafighdoost has responded: "I am just a normal person, with normal wealth, but if Islam is threatened, I will become big again."<ref name="Klebnikov" />
==References== <references />
===Bibliography=== * [https://www.theatlantic.com/doc/199603/kaplan-iran A Bazaari's World by Robert D. Kaplan] March 1996 ''Atlantic'' accessed 15-May-2009, also in (with minor changes) Kaplan, Robert, ''The Ends of the Earth: A Journey at the Dawn of the 21st Century'', Random House, New York, 1996 {{Heads of Mostazafan Foundation}} {{Authority control}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Rafighdoost, Mohsen}} [[Category:1940 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:People from Tehran]] [[Category:Iranian businesspeople]] [[Category:Government ministers of Iran]] [[Category:Recipients of the Order of Nasr]] [[Category:Islamic Coalition Party politicians]] [[Category:Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps Brigadier generals]] [[Category:Islamic Revolutionary Guard Corps personnel of the Iran–Iraq War]]

{{Infobox company | name = NASCAR Mexico| | logo = | type = Private| | foundation = 2005| | location = [[Mexico City]], [[Mexico]]| | key_people = [[Brian France]], [[NASCAR]] chairman
[[Chad Little]]
[[Edgar Matute]]| | industry = [[Auto racing|Motorsports]]| | products = Sporting activities| | homepage = [http://www.nascarmexico.com/ www.nascarmexico.com]| }} '''NASCAR Mexico''' is a joint-venture between [[NASCAR]] and [[Grupo CIE|OCESA]], a Mexican entertainment company, aiming to develop, manage and operate local motorsports events and oversee television distribution, sponsorship and licensing. The venture attempts to create marketing programs to increase interest in local NASCAR events as well as NASCAR events in the [[United States]] that are televised in [[Mexico]]. NASCAR Mexico had been responsible for the organization of the [[Corona México 200]], a former [[NASCAR Xfinity Series|NASCAR Nationwide Series]] race at the [[Autódromo Hermanos Rodríguez]] in [[Mexico City]]. It also organizes and sanctions two racing series, the [[NASCAR PEAK Mexico Series]] and the [[NASCAR Mexico T4 Series]]. The series experienced its first fatality on June 14, 2009 when [[Carlos Pardo]] was killed in an accident on the final lap. Pardo was declared the winner of the same race he was killed in after he led the final completed lap.{{cite news|title=NASCAR Mexico driver killed in crash|url=http://sports.espn.go.com/rpm/nascar/news/story?id=4259654&campaign=rss&source=RPMHeadlines|date=2009-06-15|accessdate=2009-06-15|publisher=ESPN}} ==Champions== {| class="wikitable" !Season!!Driver |- |[[2004 Desafío Corona season|2004]]||{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Carlos Pardo]] |- |[[2005 Desafío Corona season|2005]]||{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Jorge Goeters]] |- |[[2006 Desafío Corona season|2006]]||{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Rogelio López]] |- |[[2007 NASCAR Corona Series season|2007]]||{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Rafael Martínez (racing driver)|Rafael Martínez]] |- |[[2008 NASCAR Corona Series season|2008]]||{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Antonio Pérez (racing driver)|Antonio Pérez]] |- |[[2009 NASCAR Corona Series season|2009]]||{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Germán Quiroga]] |- |[[2010 NASCAR Corona Series season|2010]]||{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Germán Quiroga]] |- |[[2011 NASCAR Corona Series season|2011]]||{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Germán Quiroga]] |- |[[2012 NASCAR Toyota Series season|2012]]||{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Jorge Goeters]] |- |[[2013 NASCAR Toyota Series season|2013]]||{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Rodrigo Peralta]] |- |[[2014 NASCAR Toyota Series season|2014]]||{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Abraham Calderón]] |- |[[2015 NASCAR Toyota Series season|2015]]||{{flagicon|MEX}} [[Rubén García Jr. (racing driver)|Ruben Garcia, Jr.]] |} ==References== {{reflist}} *[http://www.sportbusiness.com/news/155357/nascar-extends-to-mexico NASCAR extends to Mexico] ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.nascarmexico.com}} {{North America topic|NASCAR}} {{Americas topic|NASCAR}} [[Category:Auto racing organizations]] [[Category:NASCAR]] [[Category:Motorsport in Mexico]] [[Category:Joint ventures]] {{NASCAR-stub}} {{Mexico-sport-stub}}

revision.text:
'''Norman Allen Adie''' (born November 25, 1946) is a former theater owner/operator/developer and confessed Ponzi schemer,<ref>[http://www.brooklynpaper.com/stories/34/50/dtg_heightscinemaponzi_2011_12_16_bk.html Moviehouse Madoff! Former Heights Cinema owner pleads guilty to Ponzi scheme], ''The Brooklyn Paper'', December 13, 2011.</ref> presently inmate number 64354-054 in the Federal Detention Center (FDC) in Miami, Florida.<ref> [http://www.bop.gov/iloc2/LocateInmate.jsp Inmate Locator], ''Federal Bureau of Prisons.''</ref> Born in Scotland, Adie began his career in London with the [[Rank Organization]] and [[Twentieth Century Fox]]<ref>[http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20080509/BIZ/805090368 Monroe Cinema Debuts Today], ''Times Herald Record'', May 9, 2008.</ref> before moving to the United States to work at [[Radio City Music Hall]].
Adie then founded Screen Arts Corporation and developed his own New York theaters in Times Square and Park Slope, Brooklyn.<ref>[http://articles.nydailynews.com/1995-11-14/local/17976594_1_film-industry-player-angelika-film-center-split-personality Theater's Opening Act Nears], ''The New York Daily News'', November 14, 1995.</ref> Adie's decade-long efforts to open a theater in Monroe, New York were delayed by protracted, well-publicized lawsuits and counter-lawsuits resulting from a troubled partnership with One Liberty Properties.<ref>[http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060318/NEWS/303189997 Building plans still stalled], ''Times Herald-Record'', March 18, 2006.</ref> "Monroe 6 Cinemas" eventually opened in 2008, but went into receivership three years later after Adie failed to pay the mortgage and property taxes.<ref>[http://www.recordonline.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20110714/BIZ/107140333 Court seizes Monroe 6 profits], ''Times Herald-Record'', July 14, 2011.</ref> Adie operated the Brooklyn Heights Cinema<ref>[http://www.brooklynpaper.com/stories/31/4/31_04littletheatertoexp.html Little Theater to Expand], ''The Brooklyn Paper'', January 26, 2008.</ref> in Brooklyn, New York, for ten years before selling it in 2011 after misappropriating the theater's finances.<ref>[http://www.crainsnewyork.com/article/20110603/REAL_ESTATE/110609943 Tainted Brooklyn Heights Cinema sold], ''Crain's New York Business'', June 3, 2011.</ref> Adie opened the Foxmoor 7 Cinemas in Marshalls Creek, Pennsylvania in 2006 only to be evicted in 2009 for failing to pay rent.<ref>[http://www.poconorecord.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20091211/NEWS/912110360 Foxmoor 7 Theater Evicted After Failing to Pay Rent], ''Pocono Record'', December 11, 2009.</ref> Adie's plans to open a movie multiplex in Matamoras, Pennsylvania in 2008 never came to fruition and resulted in a $12.7 million judgment against Adie in 2009.<ref>[http://www.strausnews.com/articles/2010/01/09/pike_county_courier/news/1.txt Movie Magic Gone Bad], ''The Pike County Courier'', January 7, 2010.</ref>
On November 23, 2010, Adie was arrested and charged with Federal securities and wire fraud.<ref> [https://www.nytimes.com/2010/11/24/nyregion/24arrest.html Theater Owner Is Charged With Fraud], ''The New York Times'', November 24, 2010. </ref> <ref> [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/klyn_cinema_owner_reel_swindler_0aw8tmUDM41aeUjZxQb3GL Brooklyn cinema owner a reel swindler: feds], ''The New York Post'', November 24, 2010. </ref> <ref> [http://www.brooklynpaper.com/stories/33/48/bh_heightscinema_2010_11_26_bk.html Feds: Heights Cinema owner was Ponzi schemer], ''The Brooklyn Paper'', November 24, 2010. </ref> He confessed to the charges in December, 2011<ref> [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/manhattan/owner_scheme_brooklyn_heights_cinema_z5TbT1uEKo6uWe1hIUtO3N Ex-owner of Brooklyn Heights Cinema pleads guilty to $500K-plus fraud scheme], ''The New York Post'', December 12, 2011. </ref> and was sentenced in May, 2012 to 20 months in Federal prison.<ref> [http://www.nypost.com/p/news/local/brooklyn/victim_de_faces_fraudster_nlgUWKWkK746N6ZqGM7ifK Victim ‘de-faces’ fraudster], ''The New York Post'', May 30, 2012. </ref><ref> [http://pikecountycourier.com/article/20120719/NEWS01/120719937/Theater-owner-sentenced-to-20-months Theater owner sentenced to 20 months], ''The Pike County Courier'', July 19, 2012. </ref>
==Notes== <references />
{{DEFAULTSORT:Adie, Norman}} [[Category:Film exhibitors]] [[Category:American businesspeople]] [[Category:1946 births]] [[Category:Living people]]

Ltd.] |attendance= |website={{URL|http://odishasolarconference.com/}} }} The '''Odisha Solar Conference''' ('''OSC''') is a conference, the gathering of professionals to develop and promote solar power across [[Odisha]]. TiE (The Indus Entrepreneur), Bhubaneswar Chapter and Canyon Consultancy together organizes the Odisha Solar Conference every year to promote and create awareness amongst the local investors about the benefits from the solar industry. The conference is held every year in association with [[Odisha Electricity Regulatory Commission]] (OERC), [[Industrial Promotion & Investment Corporation of Odisha Limited]] (IPICOL), [[Grid Corporation of Odisha]] (GRIDCO) and supported by [[Ministry of New and Renewable Energy]].{{cite web|url=http://odishasolarconference.com/about-osc/|title=About OSC | Odisha Solar Conference | 31 Oct 2014|publisher=odishasolarconference.com|accessdate=2015-02-14}} ==History== The Odisha Solar Conference have completed its three editions in 2012, 2013, and 2014. ==Conference Dates== {| class="wikitable" style="margin:auto;" |- ! style="width:130px;"|Conference ! style="width:160px;"|Location ! style="width:130px;"|Dates |- | colspan="3" style="text-align:center; background:#ff9;"| '''Conferences''' |- | Odisha Solar Conference (OSC) 2012 | Mayfair Lagoon
[[Bhubaneswar]], [[Odisha]] | October 6, 2012 |- | Odisha Solar Conference (OSC) 2013 | The Empress Hall
[[Bhubaneswar]], [[Odisha]] | November 8, 2013 |- | Odisha Solar Conference (OSC) 2014 | The Crown
[[Bhubaneswar]], [[Odisha]] | October 31, 2014 |} ==Odisha Solar Conference 2012== ===Organisers=== The Organisers of the Odisha Solar Conference 2012 were Canyon Con, SEMI India & TiE Bhubaneswar.{{cite web|url=http://panchabuta.com/2012/10/01/odisha-to-host-its-first-solar-conference-on-saturday/|title=Odisha to host its first Solar Conference on SaturdayPanchabuta | Panchabuta|publisher=panchabuta.com|accessdate=2015-02-14}} ====Knowledge Partner==== SEMI India was the Knowledge Partner for the Odisha Solar Conference 2012. ===Sessions=== *Session I: Government Facilitation, Regulatory & Finance *Session II: Recruitment Process Outsourcing (RPO), REC, Solar Roof Top & Off Grid *Session III: Warp Up & Interactive Session {{cite web|url=http://odishasolarconference.com/agenda-2012/|title=Agenda ’12 | Odisha Solar Conference | 31 Oct 2014|publisher=odishasolarconference.com|accessdate=2015-02-14}} ==Odisha Solar Conference 2013== ===Organisers=== The Organisers of the Odisha Solar Conference 2013 were Canyon Consultancy, SEMI India & TiE Bhubaneswar. ====Knowledge Partner==== SEMI India was the Knowledge Partner for the Odisha Solar Conference 2013. ===Sessions=== *Session I: Solar Policy, RPO, REC & Hybrid Projects National Solar Mission and State Solar Policies
Renewable Purchase Obligation (RPO) & Renewable Energy Certificate (REC) Mechanism
Biomass Solar Hybrid Projects *Session II: Solar Thermal & Roof-top Solar PV Solar Termal and Roof Top Solar PV
MW Scale Solar Roof-top Project in Twin City ([[Bhubaneswar]]-[[Cuttack]])
Molten Salt based 24X7 Solar Thermal Project
Case Study of MW Scale Roof Top Solar in [[Gandhinagar]]
Case Study of 2.5kWp Roof Top Project in BJB Nagar, [[Bhubaneswar]] - Net Meter *Session III: Solar Funding, Rural Electrification & CSR Solar Funding from National Agencies and International Bi-Lateral Agencies
Remote Area Electrification through Solar
Green CSR (Corporate Social Responsibility) – Solar
Case Study of a Model Solar Village {{cite web|url=http://odishasolarconference.com/agenda-2013/|title=Agenda ’13 | Odisha Solar Conference | 31 Oct 2014|publisher=odishasolarconference.com|accessdate=2015-02-14}} ==Odisha Solar Conference 2014== ===Organisers=== The Organisers of the Odisha Solar Conference 2014 were Canyon Consultancy, SEMI India & TiE Bhubaneswar. ====Knowledge Partner==== SEMI India was the Knowledge Partner for the Odisha Solar Conference 2014. ===Sessions=== *Session I: Solar Policy & Ultra Mega Solar Project *Session II: Experience Of Agencies & Investors *Session III: Potential of Solar Roof Top & Off Grid {{cite web|url=http://odishasolarconference.com/agenda-2014/|title=Agenda ’14 | Odisha Solar Conference | 31 Oct 2014|publisher=odishasolarconference.com|accessdate=2015-02-14}} == References == {{Reflist|2}} ==External links== * [http://odishasolarconference.com/ Official Website of Odisha Solar Conference] {{Odisha}} [[Category:Economy of Odisha]] [[Category:2012 conferences]] [[Category:2013 conferences]] [[Category:2014 conferences]] [[Category:Energy conferences]] [[Category:Technology conferences]] [[Category:Business conferences in India]] [[Category:Solar power in India]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2018}} '''Playbour''' (sometimes spelled '''playbor''') is a term used to describe a hybrid form of play and labour, specifically in the digital games industry. The term was coined by Julian Kücklich in 2005 in his article ''Precarious playbour: Modders and the digital games industry.'' Kücklich describes playbour as a type of free labour that fits neither traditional definitions of work nor the categories of play or leisure.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://journal.fibreculture.org/issue5/kucklich_print.html|title=Precarious Playbour: Modders and the Digital Games Industry|last=Kücklich|first=Julian|date=|website=journal.fibreculture.org|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref> Nevertheless, forms of playbour are often incorrectly perceived as being just an extension of play. Playbour is also sometimes categorized as a part of the [[gamification]] of society in general.
== History == While the term playbour itself is a relatively new invention, the phenomena it concerns – those of productive leisure and free labour in the digital games industry – have been around at least since the late 1990s. Kücklich states that since the early 1990s, the relationship between the players of digital games and the digital games industry has changed substantially. He attributes the alteration to the rise of computer [[game modification]], or "modding", as a widespread practice among players.<ref name=":0" />
=== Modding === Creating [[Mod (video gaming)|mods]] for digital games is the perfect example of playbour: a growing number of consumers of digital games are not satisfied with just playing the game, but prefer to enhance their playing experience by creating content for the game themselves. In modding we can see the very essence of playbour, or free labour: while the work of creating a modification can be seen as playful and enjoyable, it is still work. In this respect modding can be fairly similar to another form of collaborative digital production; [[Open-source software|open-source]] software development. The first game to gain a modder base of considerable size is widely agreed to be [[Doom (1993 video game)|Doom]] (1993).<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Sotamaa|first=Olli|date=3 September 2007|title=On modder labour, commodification of play, and mod competitions|url=http://journals.uic.edu/ojs/index.php/fm/article/view/2006|journal=First Monday|language=en-US|volume=12|issue=9}}</ref> The emergence of Doom mods is usually attributed to the fact that the game's code was deliberately designed to facilitate player-created content.<ref name=":1" /> The most famous modder creation is probably [[Counter-Strike]], originally a team-based mod for [[Half-Life (video game)|Half-Life]] (1998). It later also became the first commercially released mod.<ref name=":1" />
== Controversy around playbour and modding == Not only is modding a big part of [[Video game culture|gaming culture]], but it is also an increasingly important source of value for the digital games industry. Game companies usually retain the [[Intellectual property|intellectual property rights]] of the modifications. Since players need to have a copy of the original game to run the modifications, mods may add to the shelf-life of the product.<ref name=":1" /> In addition to that, mods may help with establishing [[brand]]s (e.g. Counter-Strike), thus saving companies a significant amount of money. Marketing costs often take up a large percentage of a game's budget, but successfully established brands require less marketing. Mods also increase customer loyalty and are an important source of innovation in the digital games industry.<ref name=":0" /> Another way that game companies can benefit from the modding culture is that they can recruit modders as employees who are already trained at no cost to the company.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.ephemerajournal.org/contribution/playbour-farming-and-labour|title=Playbour, farming and labour|last=Goggin|first=Joyce|date=|website=www.ephemerajournal.org|access-date=2018-02-24}}</ref>
While game companies may benefit economically from playbour, the players doing the work are not entirely uncompensated: they may obtain virtual in-game rewards or social capital such as followers on [[social media]]. The experience of play also has value in itself.<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://thesocietypages.org/cyborgology/2012/10/15/gamification-playbor-exploitation-2/|title=Gamification, Playbor & Exploitation|last=Patella-Rey|first=PJ|date=16 October 2012|work=The Society Pages|access-date=2018-02-24|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|language=en-US}}</ref> Playbour is a voluntary activity and players don't usually view modding as labour. Nevertheless, it has been suggested that playboures are exploited by the games industry.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
== See also == *[[Gamification]] *[[Modding]] *[[Mod (video gaming)]] *[[Participatory culture]]
== References == <!-- Inline citations added to your article will automatically display here. See https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/WP:REFB for instructions on how to add citations. --> {{reflist}}
[[Category:Labor]] [[Category:Play (activity)]] [[Category:Video gaming]]

Smith,''' Co-founder, '''Jared Smith,''' Co-founder, and '''Stuart Orgill,''' Co-founder | industry = Experience Management | products = Qualtrics XM Platform, Qualtrics Research Core, Customer Experience, Employee Experience, Product Experience, Brand Experience, Online Sample | num_employees = 1,300+ | homepage = [http://www.qualtrics.com/ Qualtrics.com] }} '''Qualtrics''' is a privately held experience management company, with co-headquarters in [[Provo, Utah]] and [[Seattle, Washington]], in the United States. The company was founded in 2002 by Scott M. Smith, Ryan Smith, Jared Smith and Stuart Orgill.{{cite web|url=https://blogs.wsj.com/venturecapital/2012/05/15/qualtrics-taps-accel-sequoia-for-first-ever-vc-round/|title=Qualtrics Taps Accel, Sequoia For First-Ever VC Round|author=Lizette Chapman|work=WSJ}} Qualtrics is a subscription software for collecting and analyzing data{{cite news|last=Scott|first=Martin|title=Customer research easier in digital era|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/MONEY/usaedition/2012-08-28-Efficient-Small-Business-Ecommerce_CV_U.htm|accessdate=20 February 2013|newspaper=USA Today|date=27 August 2012}} for market research, customer satisfaction and loyalty, product and concept testing, employee evaluations and website feedback.{{cite web|url=http://www.qualtrics.com|title=Qualtrics: Online Survey Software & Insight Platform|work=Qualtrics}} On November 11, 2018 it was announced that Qualtrics would be acquired by [[SAP SE|SAP]].{{Cite web|url=https://xodata.com/press-release/|title=XO Data Press Release|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The acquisition is expected to close in the first half of 2019. ==History== ===Funding & Valuation=== In 2012, the company received a $70 million investment from [[Sequoia Capital]] and [[Accel Partners]], generally considered two of the top venture capital firms in the country.[https://www.cbinsights.com/blog/venture-capital-peer-rankings/ CB Insights Venture Capital Power Rankings 2016][https://techcrunch.com/2011/05/25/top-10-vc-firms-investorrank/ TechCrunch Top 10 VC Firms] It was the largest joint investment to date by these two firms.{{cite web|url=https://techcrunch.com/2012/05/15/qualtrics-raises-70m-accel-sequoia/|title=Qualtrics Raises $70M From Accel And Sequoia: "The Biggest Software Company You Haven’t Heard Of"?|author=Anthony Ha|publisher=AOL|work=TechCrunch}} In September 2014, [[Sequoia Capital]] and [[Accel Partners]] returned in Series B funding, led by [[Insight Venture Partners]] worth $150 million, a record for a Utah-based company.{{cite web|url=http://www.businessweek.com/articles/2014-09-24/how-qualtrics-turned-online-surveys-into-a-1-billion-business|title=How Qualtrics Turned Online Surveys Into a $1 Billion Business - Businessweek|author=Joshua Brustein|work=Businessweek.com}} In April 2017 Qualtrics received a Series C of $180 million by funded by returning investors Accel, Sequoia Capital, and Insight Venture Partners.{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/organization/qualtrics|title=Qualtrics Crunchbase Profile|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The Series C was raised at a $2.3 billion pre-money valuation.{{Cite web|url=https://www.crunchbase.com/funding_round/qualtrics-series-c--dc3c0897|title=Crunchbase - Qualtrics Series C Detail|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Over its lifetime, Qualtrics has raised a total of $400 million from Accel, Insight Venture Partners and Sequoia Capital. === Filing for IPO === On October 19, 2018 Qualtrics filed their S-1 registration statement with the intention of raising gross proceeds of $200 million through an Initial Public Offering (IPO) of its Class B shares{{Cite web|url=https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/1747748/000162828018012674/qualtricss-1.htm|title=Qualtrics International INC. FORM S-1 REGISTRATION STATEMENT UNDER THE SECURITIES ACT OF 1933|last=|first=|date=October 19, 2018|website=U.S. Securities and Exchange Commission|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}. The company will list under the NASDAQ under the ticker "XM" in reference to their flagship experience management product, the Qualtrics XM Platform. When it was announced in November 2018 Qualtrics would be acquired by [[SAP SE|SAP]] (NYSE: SAP) plans for an IPO were scrapped. ===Ranking=== In 2016, Qualtrics was ranked #12 on the [[Forbes|Forbes Cloud 100]] list,{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/cloud100/|title=Forbes Cloud 100|publisher=[[Forbes]]|accessdate=29 October 2016}} moving to #6 in 2017.{{Cite news|url=https://www.forbes.com/companies/qualtrics/|title=Qualtrics on the Forbes Cloud 100 List|work=Forbes|access-date=2018-03-21|language=en}} === Revenue === Qualtrics reported revenue of $190.6 million in 2016 and $289.9 million in 2017 representing year over year growth of 52%. In 2016, Qualtrics reported an overall net loss of $12 million with free cash flow of $3.4 million. In 2017, Qualtrics reported a $2.6 million net profit with free cash flow of $21.3 million. ===Acquisitions=== In May 2016 Qualtrics acquired statistical analysis startup Statwing for an undisclosed sum. Statwing was a San Francisco-based company that created point-and-click software for advanced statistical analysis.{{Cite web|url=http://www.mrweb.com/drno/news22721.htm|title=Daily Research News Online no. 22721 - Qualtrics Buys Software Firm Statwing|website=www.mrweb.com|access-date=2016-06-29}}{{Cite web|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/qualtrics-acquires-y-combinator-funded-120000831.html|title=Qualtrics Acquires Y Combinator-Funded Startup Statwing, Making Data Science Easy for Anyone|last=|first=|date=|website=Yahoo Finance|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160625031937/https://finance.yahoo.com/news/qualtrics-acquires-y-combinator-funded-120000831.html|archive-date=25 June 2016|dead-url=|access-date=}} In April 2018 Qualtrics acquired Delighted for an undisclosed sum. Delighted had over 1500 customers at the time of acquisition.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/alexkonrad/2018/04/12/qualtrics-acquires-delighted/#4096aec927a2|title=Qualtrics Inches Closer To IPO By Acquiring The Startup Behind Ratings For Postmates And Uber|website=www.forbes.com|access-date=2018-04-12}} In June 2018, Tango Card, a digital rewards and incentives provider collaborated with Qualtrics to improve management of digital incentives and distribution of gift cards.{{Cite web|url=https://www.verdict.co.uk/cards-international/news/tango-card-partners-qualtrics-gift-card-management/|title=Tango Card partners with Qualtrics for gift card management - Cards International|website=www.verdict.co.uk|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-25}} === Acquisition by SAP SE === In November 2018, it was announced that it would be acquired by [[SAP SE|SAP]]. SAP will acquire all outstanding shares of Qualtrics for $8 billion USD in an all cash deal. SAP secured €7 billion in financing.{{Cite news|url=https://xodata.com/press-release/|title=SAP SE to Acquire Qualtrics International Inc., Sees Experience Management as the Future of Business - XOdata.com|date=2018-11-11|work=XOdata.com|access-date=2018-11-12|language=en-US}} At the time it was announced, the Qualtrics acquisition will be SAP's second-biggest purchase ever behind the $8.3 billion acquisition of travel and expense management firm Concur in 2014.{{Cite news|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2018/11/11/sap-is-buying-qualtrics-sources-say.html|title=SAP is acquiring survey software maker Qualtrics for $8 billion|last=Sherman|first=Alex|date=2018-11-11|work=CNBC|access-date=2018-11-12}} ==Research== Quantitative statistical analysis performed with Qualtrics is cited in a number of professional and academic journals.Albaum, G. S., & Smith, S. M. (2006). Handbook of Marketing Research . London, United Kingdom: [[Sage Publications]]. [https://web.archive.org/web/20070105010639/http://marketing.byu.edu/download/marketingresearch/HMR%20Chapter%2011.pdf byu.edu] (PDF)Strutz, M.L. (2008). A Retrospective Study of Skills, Traits, Influences, and School Experiences of Talented Engineers. ''ASEE North Central Section Conference'' [http://ilin.asee.org/Conference2008/SESSIONS/A%20Retrospective%20Study%20of%20Skills%20Traits%20Influences%20and%20S.pdf ilin.asee.org] (PDF) [[University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill]], Carolina Population Center (CPC), Measure Evaluation, September 2007, (57) p. (SR-07-39| USAID Cooperative Agreement No. GPO-A-00-03-00003-00), [http://db.jhuccp.org/ics-wpd/exec/icswppro.dll?BU=http://db.jhuccp.org/ics-wpd/exec/icswppro.dll&QF0=DocNo&QI0=322399&TN=Popline&AC=QBE_QUERY&MR=30%25DL=1&&RL=1&&RF=LongRecordDisplay&DF=LongRecordDisplay db.jhuccp.org]{{dead link|date=July 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}Brunson, K. W. (2008). Electronic Textbooks: An Empirical Study of Adoption Potential. ''The Liberty Business Review VI.1'', 44–55, [http://works.bepress.com/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1000&context=ken_brunson works.bepress.com] (Winter 2007–2008). ''Journal of New Communications Research'', 100, [https://books.google.com/books?id=0t1E-oihkDkC&printsec=frontcover#v=onepage&q=qualtrics&f=false books.google.com]{{cite book|title=Essentials of Marketing Research (with Qualtrics Card) 4th Edition|first1=William G. |last1=Zikmund|first2=Barry J. |last2=Babin|url=https://www.amazon.com/Essentials-Marketing-Research-Qualtrics-Card/dp/1439047545}}{{cite book|title=Business Research Methods (with Qualtrics Printed Access Card) 9th Edition|first1=William G. |last1=Zikmund|first2=Barry J. |last2=Babin|first3=Jon C. |last3= Jon C. Carr |first4=Mitch|last4= Griffin Business Research Methods|date= March 12, 2012|publisher=South-Western College Pub;|url=https://www.amazon.com/Business-Research-Methods-Qualtrics-Printed/dp/1111826927|isbn= 978-1111826925}}{{cite book|title=Modern Marketing Research: Concepts, Methods, and Cases (with Qualtrics Printed Access Card) 2nd Edition|first1=Fred M.|last1=Feinberg|first2=Thomas|last2=Kinnear|first3=James R.|last3=Taylor|publisher=South-Western College Pub;|date=February 28, 2012|url=https://www.amazon.com/Modern-Marketing-Research-Concepts-Qualtrics/dp/1133188966/ref=sr_1_2?s=books&ie=UTF8&qid=1340716864&sr=1-2&keywords=feinberg%2C+kinnear%2C+taylor|isbn= 978-1133188964}}{{cite book|title=Basic Marketing Research 7th Edition|first1=Gilbert A.|last1=Churchill|first2=Tom J.|last2=Brown|first3=Tracy A.|last3=Suter|publisher=South-Western College Pub;|date=April 22, 2009|url=https://www.amazon.com/Marketing-Research-Qualtrics-Printed-Access/dp/1439041393|isbn= 978-1439041390}}{{cite book|title=Marketing Research: Methodological Foundations (with Qualtrics Card) 10th Edition|first1=Dawn|last1=Iacobucci|first2=Gilbert A.|last2=Churchill|publisher=South-Western College Pub; 10 edition|date=October 20, 2009|isbn= 978-1439081013}}{{cite book|title=Basic Marketing Research & Qualtrics Pkg / Edition 3|first=Naresh K.|last=Malhotra|publisher=Prentice Hall|date=September 18, 2008|isbn=9780137155934}}{{cite book|author=Sue, V. M., & Ritter, L.A. |year=2007|title=Conducting Online Surveys|location= United States of America|publisher= Sage Publications}} Qualtrics became the first employee management platform measuring employee experiences through key metrics powered by predictive intelligence.[http://markets.businessinsider.com/news/stocks/Qualtrics-Simplifies-Closing-the-Employee-Experience-Gap-With-Powerful-New-Methodology-1002283007 Qualtrics Simplifies Closing the Employee Experience Gap With Powerful New Methodology] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== {{Commons category}} * {{Official website|https://www.qualtrics.com }} {{Survey data collection}} {{Provo, Utah}} [[Category:Software companies based in Utah]] [[Category:Companies based in Provo, Utah]] [[Category:Polling companies]] [[Category:Companies established in 2002]] [[Category:Statistical survey software]] [[Category:Web applications]] [[Category:Cloud computing providers]] [[Category:Cloud applications]] [[Category:Service-oriented (business computing)]] [[Category:Marketing research companies of the United States]] [[Category:Market research]] [[Category:2002 establishments in Utah]] [[Category:Companies based in Seattle]] [[Category:Announced technology acquisitions]]

'''Rajasthan Accounts Service''' (R.Ac.S.) is state service of civil services of the [[India]]n state of [[Rajasthan]]. The recruitment of officers in this service is made through competitive examination held by [[Rajasthan Public Service Commission]] [[Ajmer]] on the pattern of [[Union Public Service Commission]] [[New Delhi]].
The examination is conducted annually and is known as Rajasthan State Administrative and Subordinate Services combined competitive examination. The examination is conducted to select officers for [[Rajasthan Administrative Service]], [[Rajasthan Police Service]] and [[Rajasthan Accounts Service]] and number of other civil services.
Initially a preliminary examination is conducted in which any graduate from any discipline can appear. Those who qualify in preliminary examination take main examination and finally face group discussion and interview. A merit list is prepared and cadre is allotted on the basis of individuals choice and his rank in merit.
The first posting is as Accounts Officer. After sufficient experience officer is promoted as Senior Accounts Officer Chief Accounts Officer and Financial Advisor respectively. Some officers of outstanding performance get a promotion in [[Indian Administrative Service]].
The parent department of officers of Rajasthan Accounts Service is Finance Department of [[Government of Rajasthan]], and the officers are governed by Rajasthan Accounts Service Rules 1954.
The list of officers in this services is as follows:

{{About|the American theologian|other people named Richard Jensen|Richard Jensen (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=May 2015}} {{Infobox scientist | name = Richard A. Jensen | image = Richard A. Jensen.jpg | image_size = | caption = Jensen at [[Dana College]] in 2003 | birth_name = Richard Alvin Jensen | birth_date = {{Birth date|1934|7|4}} | birth_place = [[Fremont, Nebraska]], U.S. | death_date = {{Death date and age|2014|11|19|1934|7|4}} | death_place = [[Lakeville, Minnesota]], U.S. | residence = | citizenship = | nationality = [[Danish-American]] | ethnicity = | field = [[Systematic Theology]]
[[Homiletics]] | tradition_movement = | work_institutions = [[Lutheran School of Theology at Chicago]]
[[Wartburg Theological Seminary]]
[[Luther Seminary]] | alma_mater = | doctoral_advisor = | doctoral_students = | known_for = | influences = [[Gerhard von Rad]]
[[Søren Kierkegaard]] | influenced = | prizes = | relatives = [[Doron Jensen]] (son) | religion = [[Lutheran]] | footnotes = | main_interests = | notable_works = }} '''Richard Alvin Jensen''' (July 4, 1934 – November 19, 2014) was an American theologian, author, and the Carlson Professor of Homiletics Emeritus at the [[Lutheran School of Theology at Chicago]].{{cite web |url=https://www.workingpreacher.org/profile/default.aspx?uid=2-jensen |website=workingpreacher.org |publisher=Luther Seminary |accessdate=August 12, 2014 |title=Richard Jensen}} ==Early life and education== Jensen was born on July 4, 1934, in [[Fremont, Nebraska]]. He earned his B.A. ''cum laude'' in philosophy from [[Dana College]] in 1956. Jensen attended college with future U.S. Senator from Illinois [[Paul Simon (politician)|Paul Simon]] and was lifelong friends with Simon. Jensen later his [[Bachelor of Divinity|B.D.]] from [[Wartburg Theological Seminary]] in 1959, his [[S.T.M.]] from [[Chicago Theological Seminary]] in 1962, and his Ph.D. from [[Aquinas Institute of Theology]] in 1972. ==Academic career== Jensen studied in Chicago and wrote his [[S.T.M.]],''The Covenant in The Deuteronomic and Priestly Traditions'' under [[Robert J. Marshall]]. Jensen left Chicago in 1960 to study under [[Gerhard von Rad]] and Otto Piper at [[Princeton Theological Seminary]]. Jensen left his doctorate program after a year to become a professor and co-found the [[Ethiopian Evangelical Church Mekane Yesus|Mekana Yesus Seminary]] in [[Addis Ababa, Ethiopia]] in 1962.{{cite web |title=Introducing Dr. Richard Jensen |url=http://www.carelife.com/cancer/psych_social/rich_jensen.html |website=carelife.com |publisher=Care Life LLC |accessdate=August 24, 2012}}{{cite web |last1=Larson |first1=Duane |title=Arabic Lutheran Church Focus |url=http://www.wartburgseminary.edu/uploadedfiles/Alumni_&_Friends/eLife_Together/lt_april_05.pdf |website=wartburgseminary.edu |publisher=Wartburg Press |accessdate=August 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20051030084254/http://www.wartburgseminary.edu/uploadedfiles/Alumni_%26_Friends/eLife_Together/lt_april_05.pdf |archivedate=October 30, 2005 |df=mdy-all }} Jensen returned to the United States in 1965 to teach at his alma mater [[Dana College]]. He returned to [[Wartburg Theological Seminary]] to teach from 1972–1981. He briefly taught at [[Luther Seminary]] before leaving academia in 1982 to host the television and radio program, [[Vespers in Lutheranism|Lutheran Vespers]]. In 1997, Jensen was invited to become the first Axel Jacob and Gerde Maria Carlson Professor of Homiletics at [[Lutheran School of Theology at Chicago]], a post he held until his retirement in 2002.{{cite web |title=Advice for Evangelicalism |url=http://www.thelutheran.org/about/person_detail.cfm?person_id=509 |website=thelutheran.org |publisher=The Lutheran |accessdate=August 24, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141214205755/http://www.thelutheran.org/about/person_detail.cfm?person_id=509 |archivedate=December 14, 2014 |df=mdy-all }} Richard A. Jensen was also the Dean of the Doctorate of Ministry program sponsored by the Association of Chicago Theological Seminaries in the late 1980s. In 1986, Jensen along with his wife [[Bonnie L. Jensen|Bonnie]], assisted with merging the [[American Lutheran Church]] and [[Lutheran Church in America]] into the [[Evangelical Lutheran Church of America]]. ===Contributions to theology=== [[File:Jensen_in_office_for_Reflections.jpg|thumb|right|Jensen in his office for ''Reflections.'']] In the late 1960s the [[charismatic movement]] was causing a controversies in the Lutheran church. Jensen had become a leading scholar on the application of a Lutheran theological understanding of [[neo-Pentecostalism]].{{cite web |last1=Oh |first1=Sung Choon |title=A Critical Understanding of the Modern Glossolalia Phenomena of Pastoral Perspective |url=ftp://210.102.253.7/image01/ii100039.pdf |publisher=Chicago Theological Seminary |accessdate=August 12, 2014}} Jensen wrote his first book in 1974, ''Touched by the Spirit'', developing a Lutheran perspective on his personal experiences, and attempting to embrace the [[charismatic movement]] rather than condemn it.ftp://210.102.253.7/image01/ii100039.pdfhttp://brage.bibsys.no/xmlui/bitstream/handle/11250/162031/2012_biniel%20mallyo.pdf?sequence=1 Jensen's research was met some skepticism, but ultimately received positive reception from parish pastors, theologians, and college professors.{{elucidate|date=July 2014}} Although, Jensen's Ph.D was in systematic theology, he developed a story-based preaching technique that emphasized preaching as an oral art of communication rather than written discourse memorized or read to listeners.{{cite web |last1=Boden |first1=Jan |title=The Rev. Dr. Richard A. Jensen Presents "Thinking in Pictures," July 5–6 During ACTS Preaching Residency at LSTC |url=http://www.lstc.edu/communications/news/?a=article&id=142 |website=lstc.edu |publisher=Evangelical Lutheran Church of America |accessdate=August 12, 2014}} In 1993, Jensen published ''Thinking in Story''. This was followed by three books that understood the Gospels of Matthew, Mark, and Luke as oral narratives from which the preacher used bibilical narrative to enable the listener to participate more holistically in the stories of Jesus. Jensen further expanded his understanding of preaching to incorporate the use of art and visual images in the sermon and worship experience. This thinking culminated in the book published in 2005, ''Envisioning the Word: The Use of Visual Images in Preaching.{{cite web |title=Preaching in Post-Literate with Dr. Richard Jensen |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/Thinking_in_Story.html?id=Lb3FDnc6tR4C |website=books.google |accessdate=August 24, 2014}} ==Personal life== Richard Jensen was married to [[Bonnie L. Jensen]], [[ELCA Global Mission]] executive director (retired),{{cite web |last1=Lee |first1=Albert H. |title=Bonnie Jensen to Retire as Director of ELCA Global Mission |url=http://www.christianpost.com/news/bonnie-jensen-to-retire-as-director-of-elca-global-mission-14196/ |website=christianpost.com |publisher=ELCA |accessdate=August 12, 2014}}{{cite web |last1=Brooks |first1=John |title=Jensen Retires as Director of ELCA Global Mission |url=http://www.stlconline.org/elcanews/200211/2002111501.html |website=stlonline.org |publisher=The St. Thomas Lutheran |accessdate=August 12, 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090703174916/http://stlconline.org/elcanews/200211/2002111501.html |archivedate=July 3, 2009 |df=mdy-all }} they had three children: [[Doron Jensen|Doron]], Dodi, and Derek. Jensen was also a relative of [[Moritz Thomsen]]. A scholar of ancient texts, he could read and write in Hebrew, Greek, and Latin. On November 19, 2014, he died at the age of 80.{{cite news |url=http://www.legacy.com/obituaries/twincities/obituary.aspx?pid=173255880 |title=Richard A. JENSEN Obituary |publisher=legacy.com |work=Pioneer Press |date=November 23, 2014}} While in Ethiopia, Jensen and his wife served with fellow Lutheran missionaries Irvin and Jerene Mortenson family, parents of [[Greg Mortenson]]. While in Ethiopia they became friends with [[Luther Youngdahl]] and the Youngdahl family. Richard Jensen along with his wife Bonnie, received honorary doctorates from [[Dana College]]. ==Selected works== ===Books=== * ''Touched by the Spirit (1974){{cite book |last1=Jensen |first1=Richard |title=Touched by the Spirit: One Man's Struggle to Understand His Experience of the Holy Spirit |date=1975 |publisher=Augsburg Publishing House |isbn=0806614846 |pages=160 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=4aXwAAAACAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Richard+A.+Jensen%22+touched+by+the+spirit&hl=en&sa=X&ei=fNuNVMmBEcGnyASKvIDgBA&ved=0CDUQ6AEwAQ}} * ''Telling the Story: Variety and Imagination in Preaching (1980){{cite book |last1=Jensen |first1=Richard |title=Telling the Story: Variety and Imagination in Preaching |date=1980 |publisher=Augsburg Publishing House |isbn=0806617667 |pages=189 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=prepNAAACAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Richard+A.+Jensen%22+telling+the+story&hl=en&sa=X&ei=-NuNVLOBK8WmyATW-ICYDQ&ved=0CD8Q6AEwBA}} * ''Crucified Ruler (1987){{cite book |last1=Jensen |first1=Richard |title=The crucified ruler: sermons for Lent and Easter |date=1987 |publisher=C.S.S. Pub. Co. |isbn=0895368706 |pages=113 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ymGVV-KfWTsC&q=inauthor:%22Richard+A.+Jensen%22&dq=inauthor:%22Richard+A.+Jensen%22&hl=en&sa=X&ei=_diNVL_xPMr3yQSP-oE4&ved=0CE4Q6AEwBw |accessdate=December 14, 2014}} * ''What Is God's Plan for My Life? (1988){{cite book |last1=Jensen |first1=Richard |title=What Is God's Plan for My Life? |date=1988 |publisher=Augsburg Fortress Publishing |isbn=0806623659 |pages=98 |url=https://books.google.com/books/about/What_Is_God_s_Will_for_My_Life.html?id=yjXfumMh8JkC |accessdate=December 14, 2014}} * ''Thinking in Story: Preaching in a Post-Literate Age (1993){{cite book |last1=Jensen |first1=Richard |title=Thinking in Story: Preaching in a Post-Literate Age |date=1992 |publisher=CSS Publishing |isbn=1556735731 |pages=145 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Lb3FDnc6tR4C&dq=inauthor:%22Richard+A.+Jensen%22&source=gbs_navlinks_s |accessdate=December 14, 2014}} * ''Preaching Mark's Gospel (1996){{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WBct2JbsSEkC&dq=inauthor:%22Richard+A.+Jensen%22&source=gbs_navlinks_s |accessdate=December 14, 2014}} * ''Preaching Luke's Gospel (1997){{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-TEHAAAACAAJ&dq=inauthor:%22Richard+A.+Jensen%22+preaching+luke%27s+gospel&hl=en&sa=X&ei=YdyNVJruLde0yQSf44CwBw&ved=0CEEQ6AEwBA}} * ''Preaching Matthew's Gospel {{Infobox Organization |name = Scottish Fair Trade Forum [[File:Sftf logo.jpg|175px|alt=The official logo of the Scottish Fair Trade Forum|Full logo of the ''Scottish Fair Trade Forum''.]]<!--Non free file removed by DASHBot--> |abbreviation = SFTF |formation = 2007 |status = [[OSCR|Charity]] |headquarters = Glasgow |area served = Scotland }}
The '''Scottish Fair Trade Forum''' is a Scottish charitable body that describes its mission as '...to gain [[Fairtrade Town|Fair Trade Nation]] status for Scotland.'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishfairtradeforum.org.uk/who-we-are/vision-mission-aims/|title=Scottish Fair Trade Forum- Vision, Mission and Aims|publisher=Scottish Fair Trade Forum|accessdate=2010-04-11}}</ref> The Forum continues to promote the inclusion and use of Fair Trade products through involvement in helping individual towns, schools,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://edinburghnews.scotsman.com/latestnews/City-school-is-awarded-Fairtrade.5005440.jp?CommentPage=1&CommentPageLength=1000|title=City School is Awarded Fairtrade Status|publisher=Edinburgh Evening News|accessdate=2010-04-11}}</ref> councils <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.midlothian.gov.uk/Article.aspx?TopicId=0&ArticleId=22403|title=Fair Trade|publisher=Midlothian Council|accessdate=2010-03-11}}</ref> and public bodies <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.sqa.org.uk/sqa/42278.html|title=SQA Fair Trade|publisher=Scottish Qualifications Authority|accessdate=2010-03-11}}</ref> throughout the country achieve [[Fairtrade Town|Fairtrade Status]].
==History==
After the [[Scottish Labour Party|Labour]] and [[Scottish Liberal Democrats|Liberal Democrat]] [[coalition government]] of the [[Scottish Parliament]] engaged in talks with the [[Welsh Assembly]] over each country's commitment to the [[Fair trade|Fair Trade Movement]], the Scottish administration publicly committed to the Forum's creation on 27 January 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scotland.gov.uk/News/Releases/2007/01/29081802|title=Scotland: A Fair Trade Nation|publisher=The Scottish Government|accessdate=2010-03-11}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fairtradewales.com/about/fair_trade_country_campaign/438|title=Fair Trade Country Campaign|publisher=Fair Trade Wales|accessdate=2010-08-11}}</ref> The Forum was officially launched by the Scottish Parliament on 27 October 2007.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottish.parliament.uk/nmCentre/news/news-07/pa07-086.htm|title=Scottish Parliament to Host Fair Trade Forum|publisher=Scottish Parliament|accessdate=2010-03-11}}</ref> As Wales reached Fair Trade Nation status in 2008,<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.fairtradewales.com/|title=Fair Trade Wales|publisher=Fair Trade Wales|accessdate=2010-07-12}}</ref> the Fair Trade Forum aimed to make Scotland the second Fair Trade Nation in the world. This goal was achieved on 25 February 2013 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishfairtradeforum.org.uk/about-the-forum/who-we-are.html#.WHOJMxuLRaQ|title=Scottish Fair Trade Forum - Who We Are|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref> and was celebrated at an event in Perth on 7 September 2013 <ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.scottishfairtradeforum.org.uk/fair-trade-in-scotland/history-of-fair-trade-in-scotland.html#.WHOJVhuLRaQ|title=History of Fair Trade in Scotland|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref>
==See also==
*[[Fairtrade Town]] *[[Fairtrade Foundation]]
==References== {{Reflist|colwidth=30em}}
==External links== *[http://www.scottishfairtradeforum.org.uk/ Scottish Fair Trade Forum] *[http://www.fairtrade.org.uk/ Fairtrade Foundation]

revision.text:
{{For|other monuments with the same name|Soldiers and Sailors Monument (disambiguation)}} [[File:Detroit Photographic Company (0724).jpg|thumb|right|The Cuyahoga County Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument, circa 1900]] The '''Cuyahoga County Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument''' is a monument to [[American Civil War|Civil War]] soldiers and sailors from [[Cuyahoga County, Ohio|Cuyahoga County]], [[Ohio]]. Located in the southeast quadrant of [[Public Square, Cleveland|Public Square]] in [[Downtown Cleveland|downtown]] [[Cleveland, Ohio|Cleveland]], it opened July 4, 1894.<ref name="gifts">{{cite news| title=Gifts to renovate Soldiers and Sailors Monument sit in bank while county awaits repayment| author=Dave Davis| work=[[The Plain Dealer]]| publisher=cleveland.com| date=6 April 2011| url=http://blog.cleveland.com/metro/2011/04/county_waiting_on_renovation_f.html| accessdate=2011-06-01}}</ref> It was designed by architect [[Levi Scofield]] (1842–1917), who also created the monument's [[sculpture]]s. F.F. Schnitzer was the supervising architect who oversaw the creation of the structure. The monument is regularly open to the public free of charge.
==History and Construction== The monument consists of a 125-foot black Quincy [[granite]] shaft erected on a square base constructed of rough-hewn granite blocks trimmed in sandstone and housing a memorial building. The shaft divided by six carved bands which list the names of battles in which Cuyahoga soldiers fought and is topped with a bronze statue of the "Goddess of Liberty" signifying loyalty to United States.<ref name="Love">{{cite news| title= Historic emblems restored in the gardens of Cleveland's Soldiers and Sailors Monument| date=2 June 2010| author=Susan Love| work=The Plain Dealer| url=http://www.cleveland.com/insideout/index.ssf/2010/06/post_28.html| publisher=cleveland.com| accessdate=2011-06-01}}</ref>
Designed by Levi Scofield, a Captain in the 103rd Ohio Volunteer Infantry, the monument consists of an elevated base, surmounted by a column capped with a 15' high a statue of Freedom, defended by the shield of Liberty. He also created the monument's magnificent sculptures.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Gleason|first1=William J.|title=History of Cuyahoga County soldiers' and sailors' monument. Scenes and incidents from its inception to its completion.|date=1894|publisher=The Monument Commission|location=Cleveland|page=615|accessdate=20 June 2017}}</ref> Scofield is also known for his design of the [[Ohio State Reformatory]], located in [[Mansfield, Ohio]] and site of the film, [[The Shawshank Redemption]], as well as Cleveland's Schofield Building, known today as [[The Kimpton Schofield Hotel]].
The larger than life bronzes, viewed in the proper sequence, tell of the war’s deadly progression. The south side features the Navy, as sailors load a giant mortar at the low casualties, 48 hour [[Battle of Island Number Ten]]. The bronze features an African American, in one of the first monuments showing blacks and whites fighting side-by-side. Moving counter-clockwise (on purpose. Scofield shows that war is contrary to human nature.) the next bronze is the Artillery. The cannoneers aim and fire, but there are losses – two artillerists have been killed.
On the north side is Infantry, during a battle at Resaca, GA. where Scofield was present. Of the nine figures, three are dead. The rest have been wounded. Finally, to the west, the Cavalry statue shows all the horrors of war in ferocious, hand-to-hand combat – in frightening realism. The only rebel soldier is shot at point blank range, in a very accurate sculptural portrayal of war.
The interior provides peace and tranquility. Bronze panels mark the beginning and end of the war, as well as Lincoln’s freeing of the slaves. Another panel shows the names of 100 women of the Northern Ohio Soldiers and Sailors Relief Society. In the corner of the panel sits a Catholic nun, from the Ursuline order, who still run Cleveland’s St. Vincent Charity Medical Center. <ref>{{cite journal|last1=Notarianni|first1=Nancy|title=Hidden in Plain Site: The Soldiers and Sailors Monument|journal=Cleveland Visitor|date=July 2011|publisher=City Visitor, Inc.|location=Independence, Ohio}}</ref>
Inside the memorial building are a series of marble tablets listing 9,000 Civil War veterans that served with Cuyahoga County [[regiment]]s or were from Cuyahoga County.<ref name="wtam"/> Also inside the base are four bronze relief sculptures depicting the Soldiers' Aid Society, [[Abolitionism|Emancipation of the Slaves]], Beginning of the War in Ohio and the End of the War, as well as busts of Col. James Barnett, Scofield, and several Ohio officers who were killed in action during the war.<ref name="Caniglia"/>
==Restoration== [[File:Color Guard Grouping.jpg|thumb|right|One of the four sculptural groupings on the monument's exterior]] Restoration of the monument began October 26, 2008, and was expected to last approximately nine months with a cost [[US$|$]]1.5 million. Funds came from federal, state and local governments, veterans' and community groups.<ref name="wtam">{{cite news |url=http://www.wtam.com/cc-common/mainheadlines3.html?feed=122520&article=4472551 |title=Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument to be restored |publisher=wtam.com |author=Ted Klopp| work=[[WTAM]]-AM 1100| location=Cleveland, Ohio |date=2008-10-26 |accessdate=2009-06-29}}</ref> Work included cleaning interior and exterior stonework, structural repairs and painting, restoring chandeliers, installing upgraded heating and lighting, repairs to stained glass windows, installing air conditioning and making the monument accessible to disabled visitors. When the marble tablets were created, names were etched with acid, then inked. Over time, the dyes from the ink leached into the marble and discolored it. Workers cleaned each name and restored the marble's original patina.<ref name="Caniglia">{{cite news |first=John |last=Caniglia |title=Making Soldiers' and Sailors' Monument like new |url=http://blog.cleveland.com/metro/2009/03/making_soldiers_and_sailors_mo.html |work=The Plain Dealer |publisher=cleveland.com |date=20 March 2009 |accessdate=2009-03-23}}</ref> The renovated monument opened June 5, 2010,<ref name="reopen">{{cite news| url=http://blog.cleveland.com/metro/2010/06/soldiers_and_sailors_monument.html| title=Cleveland's Soldiers and Sailors Monument reopens| author=Evelyn Theiss| work=The Plain Dealer| date=5 June 2010| publisher=cleveland.com| accessdate=2011-06-01}}</ref> with $2 million spent on work.<ref name="gifts"/>
From the time of dedication until the 1940s, plantings around the monument depicted 24 army corps badges and 5 badges of Civil War organizations. After construction work finished, volunteer gardeners used over 16,000 plants to recreate the 5 organization badges plus two based on illustrations in the memorial room and one for the Daughters of Union Veterans. The plants cost $6,500 and were specially cultivated for the project. The 24 army badges could not be recreated because of budget constraints.<ref name="Love"/>
In 2011, researchers discovered that the names of 140 black soldiers from the area were omitted from the tablets. The commission overseeing the monument said it will add the names and others they discover through additional research.<ref name="newsnet">{{cite news| title=Black Civil War veterans to be added to Cleveland's Soldiers & Sailors Monument, honored on Memorial Day| publisher=cleveland.com| first=Dale| last=Davis| work=The Plain Dealer| url=http://blog.cleveland.com/metro/2011/05/black_civil_war_vets_to_be_add.html| date=28 May 2011| accessdate=2011-06-01}}</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|Biography}} *[[Ohio in the Civil War]] *[[History of Cleveland, Ohio]]
