{{Infobox person |name = Sophia Jansson |image = Sophia Jansson 01.JPG |caption = Jansson in 2014 |birth_name = Vivica Sophia Jansson |birth_date = {{bya|1962}} |birth_place = [[Finland]] |occupation = [[Artistic director]], Oy Moomin Characters, Ltd |spouse = |children = |parents = [[Lars Jansson (cartoonist)|Lars Jansson]] |relations = [[Tove Jansson]] (paternal aunt)
[[Viktor Jansson]] (paternal grandfather)
[[Signe Hammarsten-Jansson]] (paternal grandmother)
[[Per Olov Jansson]] (paternal uncle) |website = {{URL|http://www.moomin.fi/}} }} '''Vivica Sophia Jansson''' (born 1962)Tolvanen, Juhani: "Vid min svans"{{full citation needed|date=October 2015}} is the daughter of cartoonist [[Lars Jansson (cartoonist)|Lars Jansson]] and the niece of the famous [[Finland|Finnish]] writer and painter [[Tove Jansson]]. Jansson has worked as a [[Spanish language]] [[Language education|teacher]],[[Kooma (demogroup)|KOOMA]] [http://www.uiah.fi/kooma/addressi.php?sivu=60 Addressi] Uiah.fi: "30116. Sophia Jansson-Zambra Espanjankielen opettaja". In Finnish. Retrieved 18 September 2008. [[artistic director|creative/artistic director]], chairman, and majority [[shareholder]] of Oy Moomin Characters, Ltd,{{cite news|first = Merja|last = Ilpala|title = Muumilaaksolla menee hyvin|url = http://www.turunsanomat.fi/talous/?ts=1,3:1004:0:0,4:4:0:1:2004-05-15,104:4:224695,1:0:0:0:0:0:|work = [[Turun Sanomat]]|location = [[Turku]], [[Finland]]|date = 15 May 2004|accessdate = 2008-09-18|language = Finnish}} {{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}{{cite journal|last=Suortti-Vuorio |first=Auli |title=Tove Jansson (1914 - 2001) |journal=Finnish Design |url=http://www.finnishdesign.fi/designerbio?id=10254202 |accessdate=2008-09-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080518195205/http://www.finnishdesign.fi/designerbio?id=10254202 |archivedate=2008-05-18 |df= }}{{cite news|first = Juliet|last = Rix|title = The Moomins – a family affair|url = https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/2010/jul/03/moomins-tove-jansson-sophia|work = [[The Guardian]]|location = [[London]]|date = 3 July 2010|accessdate = 2011-01-23}} and provided direct oversight together with her father for the [[Moomin (1990 TV series)|1990 ''Moomin'' animated series]]. ==Oy Moomin Characters, Ltd== Growing up in the center of the collaboration of efforts between her aunt and father, Jansson gained an intimate window into the creative processes behind the [[Moomin comic strips|''Moomin'' comic strip series]]. As Tove's efforts became directed more at writing and the strip's production became more the effort of her father, Jansson became an active help in management of the visual aspects of ''[[Moomin]]'' as an intellectual property. In 1979, Lars Jansson founded the [[limited liability company]], Oy Moomin Characters, Ltd, now headed by Christer Timgren. According to a 2004 article in the Finnish business magazine ''Talouselämä'', Oy Moomin Characters, Ltd is [[Finland]]'s most cost-effective business, with some 80 Moomin [[licence]]s in Finland and almost 300 abroad.{{cite journal|last = Räihä|first = Soile|title = Tove Jansson, The Moomin Business and Finnish Children|publisher = [[University of Tampere|Finnish Institutions Research Paper, University of Tampere]]|date = 2005-12-18|url = http://www.uta.fi/FAST/FIN/CULT/sr-moom.html|accessdate = 2008-09-18}} It has been listed as among the top [[Creative industries|Creative Export Companies]] of Finland in 2007.{{cite web|url = http://www.digibusiness.fi/portal/content_business_channel/top_30_finnish_international_companies_in_creative_export/|title = TOP 30 Finnish International Companies in Creative Export|accessdate = 18 September 2008|last = Blomqvist|first = Irina|year = 2007|work = Digibusiness.fi|location = [[Finland]]}} Since 1993, Jansson, together with her father, has managed the production of a new series of Moomin strips which Jansson now manages solely.{{cite news|first=Maria |last=Ånger |title=När Mumin Erövrade Världen |url=http://www.nytid.fi/arkiv/artikelnt-684-1577.html |work=[[Ny Tid (Finland)|Ny Tid]] |publisher=Tigertext Ab |location=Finland |date=1 December 2000 |accessdate=2008-09-18 |language=Swedish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927073203/http://www.nytid.fi/arkiv/artikelnt-684-1577.html |archivedate=September 27, 2007 }} In 2006 Jansson took the role of director in the release of the [[Compact Disc|CD]], ''Muumipeikko ja Pyrstötähti''.Poijärvi, Timo. [http://www.muumimusiikki.com/story.html Story Behind This Album: All fun projects do have their own story. So does this CD album] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110714135503/http://www.muumimusiikki.com/story.html |date=2011-07-14 }}. Muumimusiikki.com, 2006. Retrieved 18 September 2008. In 2008, the rediscovery by Jansson of the [[Screenplay|manuscript]] for "The King in Moominland" (a TV script written by Tove and Lars in the late 60s) made news as the resulting [[Musical theatre|musical]] performed at the [[Åbo Svenska Teater]] represented the first performance of this "lost episode" in decades.{{cite news|first = Sirpa|last = Pääkkönen|title = Kansallisteatterissa kotimaisten syksy|url = http://www.hs.fi/kulttuuri/artikkeli/Kansallisteatterissa+kotimaisten+syksy/1135238534011|work = [[Helsingin Sanomat]]|location = [[Helsinki]], [[Finland]]|date = 11 August 2008|accessdate = 2008-09-18|language = Finnish}}{{cite web|url=http://www.svenskateatern.fi/sve/kungenimumindalen |title=Urpremiär 28 augusti 2008: Kungen i Mumindalen |accessdate=18 September 2008 |work=The Swedish Theatre in Helsinki |location=[[Helsinki]], [[Finland]] |language=Swedish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090202043843/http://svenskateatern.fi/sve/kungenimumindalen |archivedate=2 February 2009 |df= }} ==Sophia Jansson in film and print== Lars Jansson produced both ''Moomin'' strips as well as others including a short strip called ''Sophia'' which he produced for a publication called ''Jaana'' in 1965.[http://lambiek.net/artists/j/jansson_lars.htm Lars Jansson]. [[Lambiek]] Comiclopedia, 2008. Retrieved 18 September 2008. In May 2003, [[Diplomatic missions of finland#Europe|The Finnish Embassy]] in [[London]] arranged for events to surround the recent translation of Tove Jansson's 1972 ''[[The Summer Book|Sommarboken]]'', a novel which featured the fictionalized life of the young Sophia on an island.{{cite book|last = Jansson|first = Tove|authorlink = Tove Jansson|title = Sommarboken|publisher = Schildts/Albert Bonniers Förlag|year = 1972|isbn = 951-50-0018-1 }} During this event, publishers presented works by Sophia Jansson and [[Johanna Sinisalo]].{{cite press release|title=Brittilehdet suosittelevat Tove Janssonin ja Johanna Sinisalon kirjoja |publisher=[[Diplomatic missions of Finland#Asia|Finnish Embassy in Tokyo]] |date=2003-07-16 |language=Finnish |url=http://www.finland.or.jp/article.asp?intNWSAID=16208&LAN=FI& |accessdate=2008-09-18 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Jansson was later interviewed in June 2003 by ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' where she explained the details surrounding the story presented in ''[[The Summer Book|Sommarboken]]'' and the relationship shared between Jansson and her aunt, [[Tove Jansson]].{{cite news|first = Maya|last = Jaggi|authorlink=Maya Jaggi|title = Helsinki diary: Runes of song|url = https://www.theguardian.com/books/2005/sep/03/featuresreviews.guardianreview|work = [[The Guardian]]|location =London|date = 3 September 2005|accessdate = 2008-09-25}}{{cite press release|title = Suomalainen kirjallisuus hyvässä nosteessa Britanniassa|publisher = [[Diplomatic missions of Finland#Europe|Ministry for Foreign Affairs of Finland, London]]|date = 2003-06-04|language = Finnish|url = http://www.finemb.org.uk/public/?contentid=98095&contentlan=1&culture=fi-FI|accessdate = 2008-09-18}} She would write in more detail about this topic in 2006 in the Scandinavian Review,{{cite journal|last = Jansson|first = Sophia|authorlink = Sophia Jansson|year = 2006|title = Tove Jansson and Her Lovable Moomins|journal = Scandinavian Review|url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_qa3760/is_200610/ai_n19197999?tag=content;col1|accessdate = 2008-09-25}} and again in 2010 for ''The Guardian'', when she explained the nature of her relationship with the rest of the family including her grandmother [[Signe Hammarsten-Jansson|Signe]] and Tove's partner, [[Tuulikki Pietilä|Tuulikki]]. Jansson has been credited in such books as Tove Jansson's 1989 ''Rent Spel''{{cite book|last = Jansson|first = Tove|authorlink = Tove Jansson|title = Rent spel|publisher = Holger Schildts Förlag|year = 1989|isbn = 978-951-50-0467-3 }} and Kate McLoughlin's and Malin Lidström Brock's 2007 ''Tove Jansson Rediscovered''{{cite book|last = McLoughlin|first = Kate|last2 = Brock|first2 = Malin Lidström|title = Tove Jansson Rediscovered|publisher = Cambridge Scholars Publishing|year = 2007|isbn = 1-84718-269-0 }} among others. Jansson has appeared as the host of 1998's [[Short subject|short film]], ''Haru: The Island of the Solitary, Introduced by Sophia Jansson''.[http://www.lumifilm.fi/en/txt/Info_English_Haru.doc Haru - The Island of the Solitary - Film Info - Short Description].{{cite video|people = Sophia Jansson-Zambra (host), Kanerva Cedersteröm (director), Riikka Tanner (co-director)|title = Haru: The Island of the Solitary, Introduced by Sophia Jansson|medium = documentary|publisher = New World Finn|date = Spring 2007}} She has also featured in [[Paul Gravett]]'s 2006 [[documentary film]], ''Moomin's Memoirs,'' presented at the March 2007 Tove Jansson [[Academic conference|Conference]] in [[Oxford]].{{cite web|url = http://www.ica.org.uk/?lid=12120|title = Moomin Memoirs|accessdate = 25 September 2008|date = 22 October 2006|work = [[Institute of Contemporary Arts]]|location = London}}{{cite press release|title=Scandinavia House Programs |publisher=[[Scandinavia House - The Nordic Center in America|Scandinavia House, New York]] |year=2007 |format=[[PDF]] |url=http://www.amscan.org/pdf/07_Scandinavia%20House%20Programs.pdf |accessdate=2008-09-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917072820/http://amscan.org/pdf/07_Scandinavia%20House%20Programs.pdf |archivedate=2010-09-17 |df= }} ==Honors and awards== In 2001, following the death of her aunt, Jansson went to the UK to help Sort Of Books [[Promotion (marketing)|promote]] the [[Reissue|re-release]] of a Moomin picture book.{{cite journal|date = 21 September 2001|title = Moomin book given new lease of life|journal = Bookseller|url = http://www.allbusiness.com/retail-trade/miscellaneous-retail-miscellaneous/4651227-1.html|accessdate = 2008-09-18}} In June 2004, Jansson was invited by the [[Diplomatic missions of Finland#North America|Consulate General of Finland]] to the 31st "Dreams & Visions" Annual Children's Literature Conference in [[California]]. The Consulate sponsored her trip. Here, Jansson represented [[Finland|Finnish]] [[children's literature]] during an engaging [[lecture]] and presentation.{{cite press release|title=Tove Jansson and Moomin in California |publisher=[[Diplomatic missions of Finland#North America|Finnish Embassy in Los Angeles]] |date=2004-06-16 |url=http://www.finland.org/netcomm/news/showarticle.asp?intNWSAID=25130&intSubArtID=12361&intIGID=25&intCatID=660&LAN=EN&contlan=&Thread=25130,23487,&intThreadPosition=0 |accessdate=2008-09-18 }}{{dead link|date=May 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}{{cite mailing list|url=https://listserv.csufresno.edu/cgi-bin/wa?A3=ind0404&L=BULLETINBOARD&E=quoted-printable&P=814919&B=------%3D_NextPart_000_0006_01C4208A.28D993E0&T=text%2Fhtml;%20charset=iso-8859-1|title= Children’s Literature Association comes to Fresno in 2004|accessdate=2008-09-18|mailinglist= Listserv, California State University Fresno}} In August 2004, Jansson launched the silver [[Euro gold and silver commemorative coins (Finland)#2004 coinage|Tove Jansson and Children's Culture collector's coin]], receiving the first pressing from Raimo Makkonen, [[Chief executive officer|CEO]] of the [[Mint of Finland]].{{cite press release|title = Tove Jansson and children's culture collector coin issued today (9 August 2004)|publisher = Mint of Finland, Ltd|date = 2004-08-09|url = https://www.rahapaja.fi/en/press-releases/896/|accessdate = 2008-09-25|deadurl = yes|archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20041020203319/http://www.rahapaja.fi/en/press-releases/896/|archivedate = 20 October 2004|df = }} She served as a [[Adjudicator|judge]] in the selection of the coin's images,{{cite news|first=Arja |last=Laiho |title=Hopeinen juhlaraha Tove Janssonin elämäntyön kunniaksi |url=http://www.rannikkoseudunsanomat.fi/2004/elokuu/100804/juhlarah.htm |work=Rannikkoseudun arkisto |date=8 August 2004 |accessdate=2008-09-25 |language=Finnish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20061010084523/http://www.rannikkoseudunsanomat.fi/2004/elokuu/100804/juhlarah.htm |archivedate=10 October 2006 |df= }} as well as the series of medals that were also issued.{{cite conference|first=Raimo |last=Makkonen |year=2004 |title=Mint of Finland Group Annual Report 2004 |location=Finland |url=http://www.mint.fi/en/documents/939/RP_YEAR04_ENG_final.pdf |format=[[PDF]] |accessdate=2008-09-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070205165723/http://www.mint.fi/en/documents/939/RP_YEAR04_ENG_final.pdf |archivedate=2007-02-05 |df= }} In 2006 Jansson was invited as a notable speaker for one of the Monthly Luncheons hosted by [[International Women's Club|IWC]] [[Helsinki]].{{cite web|url = http://www.iwch.fi/activities.html|title = Activities - Monthly Luncheon|accessdate = 25 September 2008|year = 2006|work = [[International Women's Club]]|location = [[Helsinki]]}} In February 2007 Jansson was invited to speak at the [[Scandinavia House - The Nordic Center in America|Scandinavia House]] in [[New York City]]. In September 2008 Jansson participated as a member of the Committee of Honor in the renowned [[International Board on Books for Young People|IBBY World Congress]].{{cite conference|first = Jan|last = Tøth|date = September 7–10, 2008|title = IBBY World Congress 2008|conference = IBBY World Congress 2008|conferenceurl = http://www.ibby2008.dk|editor = Vagn Plenge|location = [[Copenhagen]], [[Denmark]]|url = http://www.pca.albertslund.dk/Nyheder/2008/~/media/Institutioner/PCA/PCA_filer/Ibbyprogram08.ashx|format = [[ASHX]]|accessdate = 2008-09-25}}{{dead link|date=May 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} Jansson participated in the Helsinki Design Week 2008.[http://www.helsinkidesignweek.com Helsinki Design Week 2008]. 2008. == References == {{Reflist|30em}} == External links == {{commonscat}} * [http://www.moomin.fi/moomin.htm Oy Moomin Characters, Ltd website] {{The Moomin Series}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Jansson, Sophia}} [[Category:1962 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Finnish businesspeople]] [[Category:Moomin series]] [[Category:Finnish women in business]]

Traditionally, [[market orientation]] (MO) focuses on [[Microenvironment (business)|microenvironment]] and the functional management of an organisation. However, contemporary organisations have widened their focus to incorporate more roles, functions and emphasis on the macro environment.<ref name=Elliot>Elliot, G.R.(1990)The marketing concept- Necessary but sufficient? An environmental view. European Journal of Marketing., 24 , 20-30.</ref> Firms have been concerned with short run success and often not taken into account the long-run ecological, social and economic effects from their activities. Despite growth in the MO concept, there is still a need to reconceptualise the concept with a greater emphasis on external factors that influence a firm.<ref name=Mitchell>Mitchell, R.W., Wooliscroft, B., & Higham, J. (2010) Sustainable Market Orientation: A New Approach to Managing Marketing Strategy. Journal of Macromarketing. 30 (2) 160-170</ref>
'''Sustainable market orientation''' ('''SMO''') combines the principles of MO with a macro marketing systems management approach, a stakeholder approach to integrated corporate social responsibility and marketing strategy, and the use of the sustainability management concept. SMO will serve to move corporate management beyond the micro economic and functional management prescribed by MO and provide a more comprehensive, stakeholder based approach. Mitchell et al.<ref name=Mitchell/> believe an avenue for the reformulation of MO to create SMO lies in the synthesis of MO, macromarketing, [[corporate social responsibility]] (CSR), and [[sustainable development]] management concepts.
==Background==
Unsustainable practices using traditional ideas have a number of consequences with detrimental effects to the external environment. [[Creative destruction]] implies destruction is essential for sustained [[economic growth]]. Whilst this may be economically beneficial, in many instances it can have overarching negative impacts on the social and ecological [[:wikt:environment|environment]].<ref>Tonts, M. & Greive, S. (2002) Commodification and creative destruction in the Australian rural landscape: the case of Bridgetown, Western Australia. Australian Geographical Studies, 40, 58-70.</ref> [[Marshall Berman]]'s take on creative destruction identifies that everything is built to be later torn down.<ref>Berman, M. 1983. All that is solid melts into air: The experience of modernity, Verso.</ref> This capitalistic approach relates to the idea [[tragedy of the commons]]. When firms and individuals only think about their own self-interest as opposed to society as a whole, it will result in [[over exploitation]] of finite resources with long term consequences.<ref>Daniels, B. (2007) Emerging Commons and Tragic Institutions. Envtl. L., 37, 515.</ref>
===Rise of sustainable marketing concepts===
The issues raised in these traditional self-motivated approaches pave the way for a new wave of concepts and theory.
[[Ecological economics]] promotes preserving [[natural capital]] with emphasis on [[sustainability]] and sustainable development.<ref>Soderbaum, P. (2004) Politics and ideology in ecological economics. Online Encyclopaedia of Ecological Economics.</ref> The potential negative impacts of creative destruction and tragedy of the commons are central to what ecological economics addresses, specifically the earth's [[carrying capacity]].<ref>Harris, J. M. (2002) Environmental & natural resource economics. Recherche, 67, 02.</ref> Self invested firms without sustainable practices no longer have a place in the modern corporate world.
In terms of marketing, this shift has led to the development of concepts trying to promote and incorporate these ideas see: [[green marketing]], [[triple bottom line]], [[sustainability marketing]], [[sustainability brand]],and CSR. This shift towards adopting sustainable practices is both consumer and company driven.<ref>Mendleson, N & Polonsky, M.J. (1995) Using strategic alliances to develop credible green marketing. Journal of Consumer Marketing, 12, 4-18.</ref> Governments are also looking for more long run approaches towards the achievement of sustainability.<ref>Dabholkar, U. (1989). Environmental perspective to the year 2000 and beyond: A framework for world development. Environmental Conservation, 16, 49-53.</ref> The [[Brundtland Commission]] or [[Our Common Future]] which was published in 1987 from the [[United Nations]] [[World Commission on Environment and Development]]. It is crucially important to the conceptualisation of SMO and is commonly seen as defining sustainable development. It has been the catalyst for the emergence of work on sustainability. It signaled the surfacing of issues regarding sustaining the environment as critical to international governance.<ref>Sneddon, C., Howarth, R. B. & Norgaard, R. B. (2006) Sustainable development in a post-Brundtland world. Ecological Economics, 57, 253-268.</ref>
==Definition==
SMO differentiates from other sustainable business strategies by focusing on the institutional [[marketing management]] aspects of the firm and taking a more [[Stakeholder (corporate)|stakeholder]] based approach to corporate management. Through the use of sustainable management principles the firm is able to: *Achieve objectives such as market competitiveness and [[profit (accounting)|profit]]ability through the application of economically, socially, and environmentally responsible value systems; *Use [[marketing strategies]] that anticipate and meet customer needs through the effective integration of comprehensive environmental intelligence with operational and marketing systems;<ref name=Mitchell/> *Generate positive, long-run outcomes in economic, social, and environmental terms that are acceptable for primary stakeholders who derive direct financial benefits from the firms and secondary stakeholders who gain indirect economic, social, and environmental benefits.<ref name=Mitchell/>
===Theoretical foundations===
Theoretical foundations for SMO have come from three prior sustainable marketing models.
"Socio-ecological market orientation" is the first theory that has led to the conceptualisation of SMO.<ref name=Sheth>Sheth, J.N. & Parvatiyar, A. (1995) Ecological imperatives and the role of marketing. Environmental marketing: Strategies, practice, theory, and research, 3-20.</ref> Social and ecological problems that arise from a [[free market]] approach could be mitigated by developing a framework of social, political, economic and ecological norms agreed upon corporations and society that govern the marketing based economy. However, it has a focus on corporate environmental marketing management, as opposed to sustainability and this concept relies on government regulation to ensure compliance.
A second, academically popular, approach relates to green corporate marketing strategies and lifecycle ecological management of product and service management.<ref>Fuller, D. A. (1999) Sustainable marketing: managerial-ecological issues, Sage Publications Thousand Oaks, CA.</ref> However, this approach, whilst recognising the importance of incorporating environmentally responsible management fails to incorporate social, economic and environmental management aspects that are paramount to sustainable development.<ref name=Mitchell/>
A third approach to sustainable marketing is using a macro marketing approach to sustainable corporate marketing. This criticises the traditional micro and short term economic strategies and its lack of consideration for [[externalities]] and costs associated with environmental deterioration. What is fundamental to this approach is that despite company restraints, sustainable marketing practices can improve [[efficiency]] within corporations and looks to trade off between commercial and environmental concerns.<ref name=VAN>
{{cite journal |last=Van Dam |first=Y.K. |last2=Apeldoorn |first2=P.A.C. |date=1996 |title= Sustainable marketing|journal=Journal of Macromarketing |volume=16|issue=2 |pages=45–56 |doi=10.1177/027614679601600204}}
</ref>
==Framework==
===Synthesis of market orientation and sustainability===
Market orientation has several definitions; Narver and Slater<ref name=Narver> Narver, J. & Slater, S. (1990) The Effect of a Market Orientation on Business Profitability. Journal of Marketing, 54 (4), 20-35.</ref> discuss MO in terms of [[culture]] and the fundamental characteristics of the organisation. Kohli and Jaworski,<ref>Kohili, A. & Jaworski, B. (1990) Market orientation: The construct, research propositions and managerial implications. Journal of Marketing, 54 (2), 1-18.</ref> 1990 refer to MO as the organisation wide information generation and distribution and the appropriate responses to this information considering current and future customer needs. Key components of MO include market intelligence gathering and synthesis of market information to develop and implement competitive profitable marketing strategies.<ref name=Cano>Cano, C., Carrillat, F. & Jaramillio, F. (2004) A meta-analysis of the relationship between market orientation and business performance: Evidence from five continents. International Journal of Research in Marketing, 21, 179-200.</ref> A market oriented business knows that to maximise its long-run performance it must build and maintain long-running mutually beneficial relationships and be effective in creating sustainable competitive value for their [[customers]].<ref name=Narver/>
It has been noted MO has a need to address the interests of a spectrum of social, political and business (environmental) stakeholders by corporate management.<ref name=Cano/> Its current emphasis places internal corporate dynamics as the way to achieve efficiency and profitability. The combination of MO's emphasis on internal corporate dynamics with an added reliance on long-term external social and ecological interactions creates the concept of SMO. SMO allows companies to build on advantages gained through an MO strategy to create a greater alignment of long-term commercial performance with the interests of a wider range of stakeholders.<ref name=Mitchell/> The model of corporate SMO provides for a more comprehensive, stakeholder based approach to corporate management.
===Macromarketing===
An early version of sustainable marketing was proposed by van Dam and Apeldoorn<ref name=VAN/> through the combination of ecological marketing, green marketing and sustainable marketing, resulting in the concept 'environmental marketing'. Furthermore, Kilbourne, McDonagh and Prothero<ref>Kilbourne, W., & McDonagh, P. (1997) Sustainable consumption and the quality of life: A macromarketing challenge to the dominant social paradigm. Journal of Macromarketing, 17 (4), 4-23.</ref> recognised the dilemma of corporate reliance on the dominant social paradigm and [[micromarketing]]. A new marketing [[paradigm]] in which macromarketing takes the central role was suggested with the emphasis placed upon business embeddedness in social relationships.<ref name=Mitchell/> It was said corporate marketing management should manage economic, social, cultural and environmental considerations, however marketing practitioners focused on green marketing and overlooked these broader social and environmental responsibilities required.<ref name=Mitchell/><ref name=VAN/> This is where macromarketing literature distinguishes MO from SMO. SMO combines the pursuit for economic benefits with the alignment of corporate marketing activity with social and environmental norms<ref>Varman, R. & Costa, J. A. (2008) Embedded Markets, Communities, and the Invisible Hand of Social Norms. Journal of Macromarketing, 28, 141-156.</ref> and offers a more comprehensive framework for sustainable marketing.<ref name=Mitchell/> The framework is supported by social, environmental and economic responsibilities.<ref name=Mitchell/>
===Corporate social responsibility===
As early as 1969, Lazer<ref>Lazer, W. (1969) Marketing's changing social relationships. Journal of Marketing, 33 (3), 3-9.</ref> recognised a need to bridge the gap between the [[profit motive]] and [[social responsibility]]. Orlitzky, Schmidt, and Rynes<ref>Orlitzky, M., Schmidt, F. L. & Rynes, S. L. (2003) Corporate Social and Financial Performance: A Meta-analysis. Organization Studies, 24 93), 403-441.</ref> found corporate social performance and corporate financial performance are interlinked. MO holds little commitment for corporations to meet the social and environmental expectations of society. The importance of the combination of corporate social and economic responsibility with environmental responsibility is accounted for in the SMO model thus providing a more holistic approach to corporate marketing management.<ref name=Mitchell/>
===Sustainable development===
The MO paradigm guides corporate management with narrow ecological and environmental prescriptions. Sustainable development literature extends MO's parameters with less observance towards the dominant social paradigm and economic performance.<ref name=Mitchell/><ref>Kilbourne, W., Beckmann, S. & Thelen, E. (2002) The role of the dominant social paradigm in environmental attitudes: A multinational examination. Journal of Business Research, 55, 193-204.</ref> In the past conceptualisations of sustainable corporate management and sustainable marketing have often focused on the micromanagement of ecological issues. This only recently has been developed past these views.<ref name=Sheth/><ref name=VAN/> SMO moves towards corporate marketing meeting market expectations of the responsible application of resources, environmental and social responsibility.<ref name=Mitchell/>
==Benefits==
If a firm applies SMO to their corporate management strategy it offers them a more socially and environmentally responsible business framework for profitable marketing activity to more effectively sustain long term competitiveness and survival. A firm that utilises SMO are hypothesised to gain enhancement of both brand and firm reputation based on the ability for them to have both efficient and competitive products and services.<ref name=Mitchell/> This is also complemented by societal and market recognition of the firm holding superior social and environmental management. The critical driver for these benefits to the firm will be the integration of organisational intelligence systems, [[innovation]] and continuous learning that inform and proactive marketing strategy.<ref name=Mitchell/>
Looking beyond the market place, adopting the SMO perspective will bring forth a greater understanding of societal issues and concerns. Also as SMO becomes a more integrated part of political development, it will highlight potential areas of business risk and areas where new business opportunities may lie.<ref name=VAN/>
SMO is a new systematic approach to marketing management that will ensure value to a diverse range of stakeholders by applying management criteria that will add value and assessing to internationally recognised [[Economic indicator|indicator]]s.
==Evaluation==
SMO firms will be evaluated at a [[company]], [[local community]], or regional level due to the employment of a macromarketing systems approach.Firms can no longer simply focus on the micro or internal environment of their organisations.
When evaluating SMO both proven MO indicators and sustainable development indicators should be used as a starting point.<ref name=Mitchell/> A firm must have capabilities in intelligence generation, organisation coordination, customer orientation, competitor orientation, [[responsiveness]] and profit orientation in response to a range of internal (including employees, [[investors]], customers, and [[business partners]]) and external (including [[special interest groups]], local communities, government, [[regulator (economics)|regulator]]s, and the [[News media|media]]) stakeholders.<ref>Dobscha, S., Mentzer, J. & Littlefield, J. (1994) Do external factors play an antecedent role to market orientation? Developments in marketing science, 17, 333-37.</ref> Alignment of corporate marketing management to recognise sustainable management principles such as [[sustainable consumption]] and brand management should also be incorporated when assessing a firm's commitment to SMO.<ref name=Mitchell/>
==Later developments==
===Hult and Tomas=== Hult and Tomas have developed further the issue of sustainability, with regards to market orientation. They highlight that in order for an organisation to achieve market-based sustainability they must strategically align themselves with both the consumers wants and needs of a market-orientated product and the interests of the multiple stakeholders concerned about the social responsibility issues involving economic, environmental (ecological), and social dimensions.<ref>Hult, G., Tomas. M. (2010) Market-focused sustainability: market orientation plus! Journal of the Academy of Marketing Science, 39(1): 1-6.</ref> There is also great emphasis on the importance of the Bruntland Report as the underlying backdrop for both academic and managerial work on sustainability.
==Industry application==
===Tourism=== SMO is becoming increasingly prevalent in the [[tourism]] industry with a shift from economic profit priorities towards sustainability and a sustainable tourism marketing model.<ref name=Jamrozy>Jamrozy, U. (2007) Marketing of tourism: a paradigm shift toward sustainability. International Journal of Culture, Tourism and Hospitality Research, 1 (2), 117-130.</ref> The emergence of this shift towards sustainability includes the concept of sustainable development put forward by the Brundtland Commission and the preservation of the environment for future use.<ref>Berry, S. & Ladkin, A. (1997) Sustainable tourism: a regional perspective. Tourism Management, 18 (7), 433-440.</ref> The sustainability approach adopts an integrated view of marketing, the consideration of [[social equity]], environmental protection, and economic liveability. This paradigm shift traces the evolution of marketing approaches from a consumer oriented basis towards societal, causal, green, relationship marketing alongside the consideration of the triple bottom line.<ref name=Jamrozy/> Empirical research into the practical application of the SMO as a management model in the New Zealand tourism sector \found alignment of the SMO model alignment in the strategy management of a government conservation agency and tourism SMEs. The researchers recommended replication research and evaluation in other sectors and countries.<ref name = Mitchell2>Mitchell,R.W.& Wooliscroft, B., Higham, J.(2012)</ref>
===Forestry=== Alongside tourism, the [[forestry]] industry is adapting to the paradigm shift and moving towards the embodiment of the principles of sustainable forest management. This industry recognises its responsibility to future generations and the environment. There are many other industries that could benefit from sustainable practices demonstrated in the forestry industry.<ref>Nambiar, S. E. K. (1997) Pursuit of Sustainable Plantation Forestry. The Southern African Forestry Journal, 184 (1), 45-62.</ref>
=== Agriculture=== Climate change is already affecting the agriculture sector. The net effect of climate change on world agriculture is likely to be negative, although some regions and crops will benefit, most will not. Adaptation play a significant role in reducing the climate change negative impact on agriculture and increase benefit from climate change (Easterling 1996). Producers can adapt by changing seeding dates, Dynamic fertilization and irrigation applications, and switching one crop to another according to climate changes (Barklacich and Stewart 1995).
==References== <references/>
[[Category:Marketing]] [[Category:Sustainability by subject|Market]]

{{Refimprove|date=August 2017}} '''TiE Silicon Valley''' (TiE SV) is the largest and founding chapter of the [[TiE]] brand, a non-profit organization dedicated to fostering entrepreneurship.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mercurynews.com/2009/12/09/obrien-the-influencers-of-silicon-valley-2/|title=O’Brien: The Influencers of Silicon Valley|date=9 December 2009|website=Mercurynews.com|accessdate=23 August 2017}}</ref> It provides technology entrepreneurs with mentoring services, networking opportunities, startup-related education, funding, and incubating.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/22/idUSnMKWXJQfka+1f8+MKW20141222 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2017-07-02 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150924211722/http://www.reuters.com/article/2014/12/22/idUSnMKWXJQfka+1f8+MKW20141222 |archivedate=2015-09-24 |df= }} </ref>
==History== TiE SV was founded in 1992 by a group of successful entrepreneurs, corporate executives, and senior professionals with roots in the South Asian or Indus region and was named TiE for "The Indus Entrepreneurs." It has since moved away from that focus and is open and inclusive.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/print-edition/2011/03/18/tie-executive-pushes-new-programs.html?page=all|title=TiE executive pushes new programs|website=Bizjournals.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/print-edition/2013/09/27/building-the-steps-others-will-climb.html?page=all|title=TiE: Meet the men who paved the way for South Asians to write a chapter in Silicon Valley’s success story|website=Bizjournals.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref>
TiE SV received the 2014 Innovation Catalyst Award by VC Taskforce, which recognizes venture community leaders for being catalysts of innovation and entrepreneurship. Past recipients of this award include female venture capitalist [[Ann Winblad]], the Draper family, and [[Reid Hoffman]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.indiawest.com/news/business/vc-taskforce-fetes-tie-pentium-chip-designer-vinod-dham/article_0184f596-5adf-11e4-9d37-339691dbb689.html|title=VC Taskforce Fetes TiE, Pentium Chip Designer Vinod Dham|first=News|last=Dispatches|website=Indiawest.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://finance.yahoo.com/news/tie-receive-vc-taskforce-2014-201257766.html|title=TiE to Receive VC Taskforce 2014 Innovation Catalyst Award|website=Finance.yahoo.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref>
==Organization== TiE SV is a network of general members, Charter Members, and sponsors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.realwire.com/releases/Tech-Trailblazers-Awards-welcomes-TiE-Silicon-Valley-and-ask-emerging-markets-startups-to-stand-and-be-counted|title=Tech Trailblazers - Tech Trailblazers Awards welcomes TiE Silicon Valley and ask emerging markets startups to stand and be counted|date=28 August 2012|website=Realwire.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref>
===Charter Members=== Charter members are successful, veteran entrepreneurs who are looking to give back and assist the next generation of entrepreneurs by offering their time, knowledge, and resources.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.mynewsdesk.com/tech-trailblazers/pressreleases/tech-trailblazers-awards-welcomes-tie-silicon-valley-as-industry-supporter-and-ask-startups-from-emerging-markets-to-stand-and-be-counted-788217|title=Tech Trailblazers Awards welcomes TiE Silicon Valley as industry supporter and ask startups from emerging markets to stand and be counted|website=Mynewsdest.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> As of December 2014, TiE SV has more than 300 Charter members.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://inc42.com/buzz/tie-silicon-valley-announces-first-class-billion-dollar-babies-3-startups/?hvid=5l9hLC|title=TiE Silicon Valley Announces Its First Class Of Billion Dollar Babies With 3 Startups |website=inc42.com|accessdate=2017-08-22}}</ref> This membership level is by invitation only. Since inception, this group has created upwards of a quarter trillion dollars of value worldwide.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.clearstone.com/the-country-is-absolutely-on-the-right-path-vish-mishra-president-tie-silicon-valley/|title=The country is absolutely on the right path: Vish Mishra, President, TiE Silicon Valley « Clearstone Venture Partners|website=Clearstone.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref>
==Programs== ===TiEcon=== TiEcon is TiE SV's flagship annual conference. Since 2008, more than 4,000 people attend the conference from over 40 countries.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2008/05/16/tiecon-keeps-growing-despite-economic-crunch/|title=TieCon keeps growing despite economic crunch|date=16 May 2008|website=Venturebeat.com|accessdate=23 August 2017}}</ref> It is widely considered the world's largest conference for entrepreneurs.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/nishacharya/2014/05/22/look-out-silicon-valley-america-is-catching-up/|title=Look Out Silicon Valley...America is Catching Up|first=Nish|last=Acharya|website=Forbes.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> The conference features two full days of networking and programming with thousands of entrepreneurs, venture capitalists, industry executives, and thought leaders.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.redorbit.com/news/technology/1689197/mashery_named_one_of_the_hottest_startups_of_2009/ |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150405154905/http://www.redorbit.com/news/technology/1689197/mashery_named_one_of_the_hottest_startups_of_2009/ |archivedate=2015-04-05 |df= }} </ref>
Each TiEcon, the world's 50 most promising technology startups are honored as the "TiE50." These companies are selected from more than 1,600 companies screened worldwide. As of 2011, 94% of TiE50 companies had been funded, attracted over $20 billion in investments, and 42 of the companies exited. At TiEcon 2011, [[Cloudera]], the leading provider of Apache Hadoop-based data management software and services, was announced as a TiE50 winner in the software/cloud computing category.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cloudera.com/content/cloudera/en/about/press-center/press-releases/2011/05/13/cloudera-named-among-the-world-s-50-most-promising-startups-by-tie-silicon-valley.html|title=cloudera named among the world s 50 most promising startups by tie silicon valley|website=Cloudera.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref>
TiEcon was listed by [[Worth Magazine]] in their September 2011 issue to be among the 10 Best Conferences for Ideas and Entrepreneurship.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.worth.com/index.php/component/content/article/2-make/2911-10-best-conferences-for-ideas-and-entrepreneurship |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2013-06-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130531204210/http://www.worth.com/index.php/component/content/article/2-make/2911-10-best-conferences-for-ideas-and-entrepreneurship |archivedate=2013-05-31 |df= }} </ref>
===TiE Angels=== TiE Angels is an early stage Angel investment group formed in 2010 by Charter Members of TiE SV.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://barberacorporatelaw.com/blog/2014/4/2/30-angel-invester-groups-in-california|title=31 Angel Investor Groups in California|website=Barberacorporatelaw.com|accessdate=23 August 2017}}</ref> There are about 100 investors that invest through TiE Angels.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://bits.blogs.nytimes.com/2011/12/05/indian-techie-network-bankrolls-start-ups-and-not-just-by-indian-techies/|title=Network of Indian Entrepreneurs Now Backs Start-Ups|first=Somini|last=Sengupta|website=Bits Blog|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> There is no TiE SV fund and individuals invest in their personal capacity.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://techcircle.vccircle.com/2011/07/23/india-is-absolutely-on-the-right-path-vish-mishra-president-tie-silicon-valley/|title=The Country Is On The Right Path: Vish Mishra, President, TiE Silicon Valley|date=23 July 2011|website=Techcircle.vccircle.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> TiE Angels was ranked by CB Insights as one of the Top 20 Angel groups in the nation in August 2014.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbinsights.com/blog/top-angel-groups-mosaic/|title=Ranking Angel Investment Groups|date=13 August 2014|website=Cbsinsights.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref>
Most of TiE Angels investments are under $1 million, with a focus on enterprise solutions that leverage the technological expertise of TiE members. In its first year of existence, TiE Angels invested in 11 companies with a total of about $4.5 million.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://query.nytimes.com/gst/fullpage.html|title=INDIA INK; Indian 'Angels' Back Start-Ups|first=Somini|last=Sengupta|date=12 December 2011|website=NYTimes.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> CloudVolumes, which was purchased by [[VMware]] in August 2014, was backed by TiE Angels and several individual Angel investors.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/news/2014/08/20/vmware-acquires-app-delivery-startup-cloudvolumes.html|title=VMware acquires app delivery startup CloudVolumes|website=Bizjournals.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> TiE Angels also backed CRISI Medical which was acquired by [[BD Medical]] in March 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.cbinsights.com/company/crisi-medical-systems|title=CRISI Medical Systems - CB Insights|website=Cbsinsights.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.bd.com/press-details/18508/BD-Acquires-CRISI-Medical-Systems |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150404071130/https://www.bd.com/press-details/18508/BD-Acquires-CRISI-Medical-Systems |archivedate=2015-04-04 |df= }} </ref>
===TiE LaunchPad=== TiE LaunchPad is TiE SV's accelerator program for early stage startups. LaunchPad accepts eight companies per batch, and startups are seeded with $50,000 in convertible notes and offered optional working space, infrastructure, and additional support services for a five month duration. Companies also get assistance in fundraising by presenting to TiE's network of investors at a Demo Day at the end of the program. More than 50 Charter members serve as mentors to LaunchPad companies.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.bizjournals.com/sanjose/news/2013/10/21/tie-startup-acclerator-mentors-will-be.html?page=all|title=TiE startup accelerator mentors will be investors, too|website=Bizjournals.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.massinvestordatabase.com/TiE+LaunchPad/investmentfirm.php|title=Company Information|website=Massinvestordatabase.com|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/tie-silicon-valley-launches-enterprise-start-up-accelerator-tie-launchpad-1843417.htm |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150405050334/http://www.marketwired.com/press-release/tie-silicon-valley-launches-enterprise-start-up-accelerator-tie-launchpad-1843417.htm |archivedate=2015-04-05 |df= }} </ref>
===Billion Dollar Babies=== The Billion Dollar Babies Program is an initiative through TiE SV to mentor product companies out of India who are achieving significant domestic traction and wish to scale their products globally.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://economictimes.indiatimes.com/small-biz/startups/billion-dollar-babies-why-indian-american-entrepreneurs-are-betting-on-born-in-india-startups/articleshow/45588539.cms?intenttarget=no|title=Billion Dollar Babies: Why Indian-American entrepreneurs are betting on born-in-India startups|date=21 December 2014|newspaper=[[The Economic Times]]}}</ref> It is managed by BV Jagadeesh, Raju Reddy (founder of [[Sierra Atlantic]]), and TiE SV President Venktesh Shukla.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/business/india-business/TiE-in-Silicon-Valley-rolls-out-Billion-Dollar-Babies-to-help-Indian-startups/articleshow/45000681.cms|title=TiE in Silicon Valley rolls out Billion Dollar Babies to help Indian startups |newspaper=[[Times of India]]|accessdate=2017-08-23}}</ref> The pilot round of this program began January 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://in.finance.yahoo.com/news/tie-launches-billion-dollar-babies-155009571.html|title=TiE launches 'billion dollar babies' project for startups|website=In.finance.yahoo.com|accessdate=23 August 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.telegraphindia.com/external/display.jsp?mode=details&id=41981 |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2015-04-03 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160610152818/http://www.telegraphindia.com/external/display.jsp?mode=details |archivedate=2016-06-10 |df= }} </ref>
==References== {{Reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Tone|date=March 2009}} '''ToolBank''' is a registered term or 'word mark' registered with the U.S. Patent & Trademark Office used to identify the nonprofit tool lending program model created by the [http://atlanta.toolbank.org Atlanta Community ToolBank]. Each ToolBank increases the impact of its local charitable sector by lending tools to organizations for use in the fulfillment of their missions. The available inventory of a typical ToolBank includes tools for landscaping, carpentry, plumbing, masonry as well as power tools, ladders, wheelbarrows, and others. The Atlanta Community ToolBank is currently the largest ToolBank in existence, with over 200 tool types in its lending inventory. The available inventory of the Atlanta Community ToolBank can be found [http://atlanta.toolbank.org/Portals/18/TRF.pdf here]{{Dead link|date=July 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=no }}. Nine ToolBanks are currently lending tools in Atlanta GA, Baltimore MD, Charlotte NC, Cincinnati OH, Houston TX, Phoenix AZ, Portland OR, Richmond VA, and Chicago, IL. The national network of ToolBanks is administered by the parent organization [http://www.toolbank.org ToolBank USA], which was founded in 2008 to replicate the impact of the Atlanta ToolBank in cities beyond Atlanta. In 2014, ToolBank USA launched ToolBank Disaster Services, a program to deliver tools to communities affected by disaster. ToolBanks loaned $5.8M worth of tools and equipment to charitable organizations in 2015. The ToolBank program model differs from the more common [[tool library]] model in that ToolBanks loan tools exclusively to other charitable organizations; ToolBank tools are not available to individuals. The ToolBank inventory is designated for the purpose of increasing the impact of the nonprofit sector and less formalized grassroots organizations. Typical borrowers of ToolBank tools include faith-based organizations, public schools, neighborhood organizations, public/private partnerships with community-oriented missions, social clubs with a service mission, gardening clubs, and others. Proof of charitable intent is verified prior to accessing ToolBank tools. The ToolBank performs three primary functions: 1. '''Tool Lending:''' The ToolBank lends tools of all kinds for use in volunteer projects, facility maintenance and improvement projects, community improvement events, and special events. 2. '''Tool Advocacy:''' ToolBank staff advocates for the complete and timely return of all borrowed tools, to guarantee the long-term sustainability of available inventory. Staff also seeks compensation for lost tools and tools returned late. 3. '''Tool Maintenance:''' The ToolBank performs [[Planned maintenance|routine maintenance]] and repairs on all equipment to ensure good condition and to extend the lifespan of the inventory. This function is typically performed by volunteers and community service workers. Through these three functions, local community organizations may benefit by:
ensuring that all participating volunteers are properly equipped;
engaging larger volunteer groups;
performing a broader scope of service projects;
engaging more highly skilled volunteers; and
eliminating tool purchase, repair, and storage costs. '''ToolBank''' is a registered mark of the Atlanta Community ToolBank.{{US servicemark|78934493}} The Atlanta Community ToolBank granted a Right to License to [http://www.toolbank.org ToolBank USA] in 2008. ToolBank USA is a nonprofit organization created in February 2008, charged with the successful nationwide replication of the ToolBank program model. ToolBank USA was launched by a founding grant from [http://www.homedepotfoundation.org/ The Home Depot Foundation]. == History == The '''Atlanta Community ToolBank''' originated in Atlanta GA as an offshoot of a charitable no-cost home repair program known as Community Reinvestment Inc (CRI), founded in 1990. CRI's tool inventory grew organically as a result of volunteers donating equipment in support of the program. Local neighborhood associations and churches periodically borrowed CRI's tools for their own cleanup days and volunteer events, giving rise to the core concept of the ToolBank. The specific origin of the term ToolBank is unknown; CRI began offering the ToolBank as a formal program in 1992. ==References== {{Reflist}} [[Image:ToolBank wheelbarrows.jpg]] [[Category:Community-building organizations]] [[Category:Neighborhood associations]] [[Category:Community development]] [[Category:Volunteering in the United States]] [[Category:Construction industry]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2013}} {{Infobox treaty | name = C144
Tripartite Consultation (International Labour Standards) Convention | long_name = Convention concerning tripartite consultations to promote the implementation of international labour standards | image =Tripartite.png | image_width =250 | caption =Contracting States to the Convention | type = | date_drafted = | date_signed = 21 June 1976 | location_signed =Geneva | date_sealed = | date_effective = 16 May 1978 | condition_effective = 2 ratifications | date_expiration = | signatories = | parties =139 | ratifiers = | depositor = Director-General of the International Labour Office | language = | languages = French and English | wikisource = }} The '''Tripartite Consultation (International Labour Standards) Convention, 1976''', officially the '''Convention concerning tripartite consultations to promote the implementation of international labour standards''' is an [[International Labour Organization]] [[International Labour Organization#International Labour Conference|Convention]], which governs the process for implementation of measures regarding ILO conferences. It requires tripartite consultation before ratification, implementing legislation or denouncement of conventions. As of June 2015, the convention had been ratified by 139 member states. The convention is also known as convention number 144 on the [[List of International Labour Organization Conventions]].[http://www3.austlii.edu.au/au/other/dfat/treaties/1980/7.html “Convention (No. 144) concerning Tripartite Consultations to Promote the Implementation of International Labour Standards. ATS 7 of 1980”]. Australasian Legal Information Institute, Australian Treaties Library. Retrieved on 15 April 2017. ==External links== *[http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:12100:0::NO:12100:P12100_INSTRUMENT_ID:312289 Treaty text]. *[http://www.ilo.org/dyn/normlex/en/f?p=1000:11300:0::NO:11300:P11300_INSTRUMENT_ID:312289 Ratifications]. ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:International Labour Organization conventions]] {{for|the similarly named theatre in Los Angeles|Ace Hotel Los Angeles}} {{Infobox building | name = United Artists Theatre Building | image = United Artists Theatre Building.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = | location = 150 Bagley Street
[[Detroit]], [[Michigan]] | coordinates = {{coord|42.335549|-83.052328|region:US-CA|display=inline,title}} | completion_date = 1928 | building_type = Commercial offices
''proposed [[residential]]'' | antenna_spire = | roof = {{convert|230|ft|abbr=on}} | top_floor = | floor_count = 18 | elevator_count = | cost = | floor_area = {{convert|217300|sqft|abbr=on}} | architect = [[Charles Howard Crane]]
[[Elmer George Kiehler]] | structural_engineer= | main_contractor = | developer = | owner = | management = | references = {{emporis|156970}}{{skyscraperpage|25304}} }} The '''United Artists Theatre Building''' is a [[vacant]] [[high-rise]] tower in downtown [[Detroit]], [[Michigan]], standing at 150 Bagley Avenue. It was built in 1928 and stands 18 stories tall. The building was designed by architect [[C. Howard Crane]] in the [[renaissance revival]] architectural style, and is made mainly of [[brick]]. Until December 29, 1971, it was a first-run movie house and office space, and then after that, the theatre saw sporadic usage until 1973. The [[United Artists]] Theatre, designed in a [[Spanish Gothic architecture|Spanish-Gothic design]], sat 2,070 people, and after closing served from 1978 to 1983 as the [[Detroit Symphony Orchestra]]'s recording theater. After the theater closed, the office block struggled as tenants moved to suburbs. It finally closed in 1984. An original 10-story, vertical UA sign was replaced in the 1950s with a [[marquee (sign)|marquee]] that remained until 2005. The building once shared a lot with the now demolished [[Hotel Tuller]]. In preparation for the [[Super Bowl XL|2006 NFL Super Bowl]], graffiti was removed from all the windows of the building, and the lower levels received a coat of black paint to hide the [[graffiti]] work at the base of the building. The old theater marquee was also removed. In 2006, [[Ilitch Holdings, Inc.|Ilitch Holdings]] announced it would market the building.{{cite news|author=Lisa M. Collins |title=Ilitches Lift City Hopes |url=http://detnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060113/BIZ/601130398 |work=The Detroit News |date=13 January 2006 |accessdate=30 September 2010 |deadurl=yes }} Despite a [https://150bagleydetroit.com/ promotional website] created in 2017 and assurances of an intent to redevelop the historically significant structure, Ilitch Holdings has yet to begin any redevelopment. The company has a history of buying historic properties, voicing an intent to redevelop them, and later turning them into parking lots following increased decay.{{Cite news|url=http://www.crainsdetroit.com/article/20170219/NEWS/170219840/for-preservationists-ilitch-leaves-a-complex-legacy|title=For preservationists, Ilitch leaves a complex legacy|date=2017-02-18|work=Crain's Detroit Business|access-date=2018-04-18}}{{Cite news|url=https://detroit.curbed.com/2018/2/23/17043956/leveling-cass-corridor-foxtown-surface-parking-lots|title=The leveling of Cass Corridor and Foxtown|work=Curbed Detroit|access-date=2018-04-18}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.metrotimes.com/news-hits/archives/2017/08/24/preservationists-call-on-ilitch-family-to-halt-illegal-demolition-plans-in-cass-corridor|title=Preservationists call on Ilitch family to halt 'illegal' demolition plans in Cass Corridor|last=Ikonomova|first=Violet|work=Detroit Metro Times|access-date=2018-04-18|language=en}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{Cite book |author1=Hauser, Michael |author2=Marianne Weldon |lastauthoramp=yes | title= Downtown Detroit's Movie Palaces (Images of America)| year=2006 | publisher= Arcadia Publishing | isbn=0-7385-4102-8}} *{{Cite book |author1=Hill, Eric J. |author2=John Gallagher |lastauthoramp=yes | title=AIA Detroit: The American Institute of Architects Guide to Detroit Architecture| year=2002 | publisher= Wayne State University Press | isbn=0-8143-3120-3}} *{{Cite book | author=Meyer, Katherine Mattingly and Martin C.P. McElroy with Introduction by W. Hawkins Ferry, Hon A.I.A.| title=Detroit Architecture A.I.A. Guide Revised Edition | year= 1980| publisher= Wayne State University Press| isbn = 0-8143-1651-4}} *{{Cite book | author=Sharoff, Robert | title=American City: Detroit Architecture| publisher=Wayne State University Press| year=2005| isbn=0-8143-3270-6}} ==External links== * [https://web.archive.org/web/20110103193739/http://buildingsofdetroit.com/places/ua United Artists Theatre] at ''Buildings of Detroit'' {{dead link|date=April 2014}} * [https://www.theguardian.com/artanddesign/gallery/2011/jan/02/photography-detroit?%2F%3Fpicture=370173054&index=0#/?picture=370173054&index=0] recent image of the interior of the theatre. {{Detroit Theatre District}} {{Architecture of metropolitan Detroit}} [[Category:Theatres in Detroit]] [[Category:Cinemas and movie theaters in Michigan]] [[Category:Downtown Detroit]] [[Category:United Artists Theatre buildings|Theatre Building, Detroit]] [[Category:Skyscraper office buildings in Detroit]] [[Category:Unused buildings in Michigan]] [[Category:Office buildings completed in 1928]] [[Category:Theatres completed in 1928]] [[Category:1928 establishments in Michigan]]

{{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox Prime Minister | honorific-prefix = | name = Alhaji Usman Boie Kamara |nationality = Sierra Leonean | honorific-suffix = | image = Usman Boie Kamara (cropped).jpg | imagesize = | caption=Usman Boie Kamara at a WTO conference in [[Bali]], December 2013 | birth_date = | birth_place = [[Freetown]], Sierra Leone |death_date= |death_place= |children = Three children | ethnicity = | office= [[Minister of Trade and Industry (Sierra Leone)|Minister of Trade and Industry]] |term_start= 16 January 2013 |term_end= | monarch = |vicepresident = | predecessor = [[Richard Konteh]] | successor = | office2 = | term_start2 = | term_end2 = | primeminister2 = | predecessor2 = | successor2 = | office3 = | term_start3 = | term_end3 = | primeminister3 = | predecessor3 = | successor3 = | office4 = | term_start4 = | term_end4 = | primeminister4 = | predecessor4 = | successor4 = | office5 = | term_start5 = | term_end5 = | predecessor5 = | successor5 = | profession = [[Mining engineer]], businessman | signature = | party = [[Sierra Leone People's Party]] (SLPP) (until 2012)
[[All People's Congress]] (APC) (2012–present) |residence = [[Freetown]], Sierra Leone | alma_mater = [[Imperial College|Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine]] London, United Kingdom |spouse = | website = }} '''Alhaji Usman Boie Kamara''' is a [[Sierra Leonean]] politician, businessman and [[mining engineer]] who has been [[Minister of Trade and Industry (Sierra Leone)|Minister of Trade and Industry]] of Sierra Leone since 2013. He previously worked as director of the Sierra Leone National Diamond Mining Company (NDMC).http://www.ubk2012.com/abouthttp://www.ubk2012.com/why_ubkhttp://news.sl/drwebsite/publish/printer_200518258.shtml Born and raised in [[Freetown]] to ethnic [[Mandingo people of Sierra Leone|Mandingo]] parents, Usman Boie has a master's degree in [[mining engineering]] and Mineral Production management from [[Imperial College|Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine]] in London. His father [[Mohamed Boie Kamara]] was a prominent member of the [[Sierra Leone People's Party]] (SLPP) and served as the party's treasurer during the late 1960s and early 1970s. Mohamed Boie Kamara was also a close ally of Prime Minister [[Albert Margai]]. Usman Boie Kamara unsuccessfully sought the nomination of the SLPP for the [[Sierra Leone presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]], placing second behind former [[Military dictatorship|military ruler]] [[Julius Maada Bio]], who won the SLPP nomination at the party's convention held on 31 July 2011 at the miatta hall in Freetown.{{Cite web |url=http://www.sierraexpressmedia.com/archives/27181 |title=Archived copy |access-date=17 November 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120527150221/http://www.sierraexpressmedia.com/archives/27181 |archive-date=27 May 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }}http://www.thenewpeople.com/front-page/item/1214-usman-boie-kamara-is-still-slpp After he lost the SLPP nomination to Julius Maada, Usman Boie Kamara [[defected]] from the SLPP in June 2012 and joined the ruling APC. He was officially welcomed and given an APC membership card by President [[Ernest Bai Koroma]] himself.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thepatrioticvanguard.com/spip.php?article6559|title=Freetown: Usman Boie Kamara and YD Kamara Join APC|last=Vanguard|first=The Patriotic|date=2012-06-11|work=The Patriotic Vanguard|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en}} Usman Boie is a devout [[Muslim]] and a fluent speaker of his native [[Mandingo language]]. He is married and has three children. ==Early life and family background== Alhaji Usman Boie Kamara was born and raised in [[Freetown]], the capital of [[Sierra Leone]] to prominent [[Mandinka people|Mandingo]] parents. Usman Boie grew up in the neighbourhood of [[Magazine Cut]] in the East End of Freetown.http://www.sierraexpressmedia.com/archives/36294http://www.sierraexpressmedia.com/archives/30478 Usman Boie was raised in a Mandingo family and he is a fluent speaker of the [[Mandinka language|Mandingo language]]. Usman Boie's father [[Mohamed Boie Kamara]] was a wealthy businessman and a popular member of the [[Sierra Leone People's Party]] (SLPP), serving as the treasurer of the party during the 1960s and 1970s.http://news.sl/drwebsite/publish/printer_200518258.shtmlhttp://www.sierraexpressmedia.com/archives/19813 Mohamed Boie Kamara worked closely with other respected SLPP members including [[Albert Margai]], [[Kande Bureh]], [[Mohamed Sanusi Mustapha]], and [[Alhaji A.B Tejan Jalloh]] to ensure the SLPP's victory in national and local elections across the country. As a young boy, Usman Boie traveled with his father to attend SLPP meetings, conventions and activities across Sierra Leone. When Prime Minister Albert Margai visited the Madingo Mosque in Freetown in 1965 for Friday prayer, it was Mohamed Boie Kamara who introduced him to the Muslim crowd. ==Education and career== Usman Boie Kamara is a graduate of the Prince of Wales Secondary school in Freetown. He later won a scholarship to study at the Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine in London, England. After he successfully completed his master's degree in [[mining engineering]] and Mineral Production Management from [[Imperial College of Science, Technology and Medicine]], Usman Boie was employed by the government of Sierra Leone as a mining engineer in [[Kenema]] in 1972 under the Ministry of Mines and Mineral Resources.http://www.ubk2012.com/2010/12/usman-boie-kamara-%E2%80%93-sierra-leone%E2%80%99s-vision-to-a-brighter-future Boie Kamara quickly rose to Assistant Director of Mines, Deputy Director of Mines and finally, Director of Mines in 2008. Usman Boie was later appointed as general manager of the [[Sierra Leone National Diamond Mining Company]] (NDMC), spending three years in the position. [http://www.ubk2012.com/about] Usman Boie's greatest achievement in the position was the development of the Kimberley Process Certification Scheme (KPCS), a scheme designed to distinguish and certify Sierra Leone's rough diamonds from [[blood diamond]]s. Usman also acted as a mining consultant to the United Kingdom, [[Botswana]], [[Zambia]] and [[Lesotho]]. ==Political career== Usman Boie Kamara unsuccessfully sought the nomination of the SLPP for the [[Sierra Leone presidential election, 2012|2012 presidential election]], placing second behind former [[Military dictatorship|military ruler]] [[Julius Maada Bio]], who won the SLPP nomination at the party's convention held on 31 July 2011 at the miatta hall in Freetown.{{Cite web |url=http://www.sierraexpressmedia.com/archives/27181 |title=Archived copy |access-date=17 November 2012 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120527150221/http://www.sierraexpressmedia.com/archives/27181 |archive-date=27 May 2012 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} After losing the election to Julius Maada Bio on 31 July 2011, there were great division among SLPP supporters and within the SLPP party itself. [http://www.sierraleoneview.com/news174.html] Some SLPP officials, including the SLPP chairman of the [[Western Area]] branch [[Lansana Fadika]], the party's young generation leader [[Blamoh Robert]] and regional Secretary [[Alpha Mohamed Alghali]] resigned from the party in protest at Bio's nomination.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cocorioko.net/?p=16735|title=DSC01227 – Cocorioko|website=www.cocorioko.net|language=en-US|access-date=2018-06-25}} Some of Usman Boie's supporters called for him to leave the SLPP and form his own party to challenge President [[Ernest Bai Koroma]]. However, on 4 September 2011 Usman Boie delivered a speech in front of 15,000 of his supporters and senior members of the SLPP at the Attouga Stadium in Freetown.http://www.sierraexpressmedia.com/archives/17745 In his speech, he called for unity within the SLPP and gave his full support to Maada Bio ahead of the 2012 presidential election. Usman Boie stated that nothing would stop the SLPP from winning the 2012 elections and party members should be focused on how to win the 2012 elections.http://www.thenewpeople.com/front-page/item/1214-usman-boie-kamara-is-still-slpphttp://www.sierraexpressmedia.com/archives/29027 Osman Boie focused his speech on criticising President Koroma's government. In June 2012, Usman Boie Kamara surprisingly defected from the SLPP and joined the ruling APC. He was officially welcomed and given an APC membership card by President Koroma himself.{{Cite news|url=http://www.thepatrioticvanguard.com/spip.php?article6559|title=Freetown: Usman Boie Kamara and YD Kamara Join APC|last=Vanguard|first=The Patriotic|date=2012-06-11|work=The Patriotic Vanguard|access-date=2018-06-25|language=en}} In January 2013, Usman Boie Kamara was chosen by President Koroma to serve as Minister of Trade and Industry in his new second term cabinet. He was approved by the [[Sierra Leone House of Parliament]] on 15 January 2013http://en.starafrica.com/news/sleone-mps-give-nod-to-12-govt-appointees.html and was sworn in as Minister of Trade and Industry on 16 January 2013 at [[State House (Sierra Leone)|State House]] in Freetown. ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *http://www.ubk2012.com/about *http://www.sierraexpressmedia.com/archives/19813 *http://www.ubk2012.com/2010/12/usman-boie-kamara-%E2%80%93-sierra-leone%E2%80%99s-vision-to-a-brighter-future *http://thenewpeople.com/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=538:adminthenewpeoplecom&catid=60:ariogbogmailcom&Itemid=101 {{DEFAULTSORT:Kamara, Usman Boie}} [[Category:Sierra Leonean businesspeople]] [[Category:All People's Congress politicians]] [[Category:Sierra Leonean politicians]] [[Category:Sierra Leonean Muslims]] [[Category:Mandinka]] [[Category:Living people]]

'''Walter Rathbone Bacon''' (February 22nd, 1845 - November 14th, 1917) was an American capitalist who organised a system of tramways in Europe.<ref>[http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1917/11/15/102650638.html?pageNumber=13 ''New York Times'' November 15, 1917]</ref> Over his career, Bacon acted as director of [[Imperial Tramways Company]], London Street Tramways Company, [[Corris Railway]] Company, Bell Punch Company Ltd., Hull Street Tramways Company, North Metropolitan Tramway Company and Belfast Street Tramways Company.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=M5DVAAAAMAAJ&pg=PA298&dq=walter+rathbone+bacon+trams&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CB4Q6wEwAGoVChMIgefPxaSmxwIVwvceCh0pIwSc#v=onepage&q=walter%20rathbone%20bacon%20trams&f=false| ''Duncan's Manual of British, Foreign and Colonial Tramway, Omnibus & Electric Railway Companies'', 1896, pg. 298]</ref><ref> [https://books.google.com/books?id=F-4NAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA349&dq=W.+R.+bacon+trams&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDYQ6wEwBWoVChMIoJbH9KOmxwIVxSseCh0M7wAc#v=onepage&q=W.%20R.%20bacon%20trams&f=false| ''The Stock Exchange Book For 1883'', 1883, pg. 345]</ref><ref> [https://books.google.com/books?id=F-4NAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA349&dq=W.+R.+bacon+trams&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDYQ6wEwBWoVChMIoJbH9KOmxwIVxSseCh0M7wAc#v=onepage&q=W.%20R.%20bacon%20trams&f=false| ''The Stock Exchange Book For 1883'', 1883, pg. 404]</ref><ref> [https://books.google.com/books?id=F-4NAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA349&dq=W.+R.+bacon+trams&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDYQ6wEwBWoVChMIoJbH9KOmxwIVxSseCh0M7wAc#v=onepage&q=W.%20R.%20bacon%20trams&f=false| ''The Stock Exchange Book For 1883'', 1883, pg. 346]</ref><ref> [https://books.google.com/books?id=F-4NAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA349&dq=W.+R.+bacon+trams&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CDYQ6wEwBWoVChMIoJbH9KOmxwIVxSseCh0M7wAc#v=onepage&q=W.%20R.%20bacon%20trams&f=false| ''The Stock Exchange Book For 1883'', 1883, pg. 349]</ref><ref>'The Hamberg, Altona and District Tramway Company, Ltd.' in ''Truth'', Vol 13, London, April 12 1883, pg. 524 </ref> [[File:Virginia and Walter Rathbone Bacon with relatives and friends.jpg|thumb|Circa 1892. Seated: Walter Rathbone Bacon, Gifford Pinchot, Virginia P. Bacon; Standing: Emily Sloane, Adele Sloane, George Vanderbilt]]
In 1882, in [[Bordeaux]], France, Bacon married [[Virginia P. Bacon|Virginia Purdy Barker]], the youngest granddaughter of business magnate, [[Cornelius Vanderbilt]].<ref>''The Standard'', Friday March 10, issue 1785 (London: 1882), p. 1. Accessed through ''19th Century British Library Newspapers Part II''</ref> Bacon and his wife spent most of their time abroad, particularly in London and at Netherdale Estate, their Manor house in [[Turriff]], Scotland. However, after the outbreak of [[World War I]] travel to Europe became more difficult and the Bacons remained in New York.<ref name="jstor.org">[https://www.jstor.org/stable/25589459?seq=1#page_scan_tab_contents ''American Art News'', April 12, 1919]</ref><ref name="jstor.org"/><ref>{{cite book|title=Social Register, Summer ...: Contains the Summer Addresses of Residents of New York, Washington, Philadelphia, Chicago, Boston and Baltimore|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ffZBAQAAMAAJ&pg=PA15|year=1913|publisher=Social Register Association|page=15}}</ref>
Walter, with his brother [[Edward R. Bacon]], a lawyer, acted as president of the Knickerbocker Apartments at 247 Fifth Avenue, where the two lived with Walter's wife.<ref>[http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1917/11/15/102650638.html?pageNumber=13 ''New York Times'' November 15, 1917]</ref><ref>[https://archive.org/stream/ldpd_5767518_000#page/n23/mode/2up| ''The Elite of New York, Society List and Club' Register'', New York, 1915, pg. 17</ref> The Knickerbocker apartments, in William B. Duncan's former mansion, were sold to the newly formed gentlemen's club, the [[Knickerbocker Club]]. The Knickerbocker club was formed out of the [[Union Club of the City of New York]], by a group of members exasperated with the admittance of younger, less traditional members.<ref>[http://daytoninmanhattan.blogspot.com/2012/09/the-lost-1882-knickerbocker-apartments.html Tom Miller, ''The Lost 1882 Knickerbocker Apartments'', September 3, 2012]</ref> Walter was also a member of [[Racquet and Tennis Club]], in New York and The [[Reform Club]], in London.<ref>[https://books.google.com/books?id=ZJVYAAAAMAAJ&q=walter+rathbone+bacon+reform+club&dq=walter+rathbone+bacon+reform+club&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0CCcQ6wEwAGoVChMI4YKinK-mxwIVAVc-Ch22GQDk| D. K. MacDowell, ''Commodore Vanderbilt and his Family: A Biographical Account of the Descendants of Cornelius and Sophia Johnson Vanderbilt'', 1989, pg. 69]</ref>
Walter died in his Fifth Avenue apartment on November 14th, 1917.<ref>[http://timesmachine.nytimes.com/timesmachine/1917/11/15/102650638.html?pageNumber=13 ''New York Times'' November 15, 1917]</ref> In 1911, Virginia established the Walter Rathbone Bacon Fellowship at the Smithsonian Institution in memory of her husband.<ref>http://www.smithsonianofi.com/walter-rathbone-bacon-fellowship/</ref>
